original: Dīgha Nikāya 1
analyzed: dīgha nikāya
translated: Long Discourses

original: Brahmajālasutta
analyzed: brahmajālasutta
translated: The Brahmajāla Sutta

original: 1. Paribbājakakathā
analyzed: paribbājaka kathā
translated: . The Discussion with the Wandering Sectarians

original: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
analyzed: evam me suta
translated: Thus have I heard.

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā antarā ca rājagahaṁ antarā ca nāḷandaṁ addhānamaggappaṭipanno hoti mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṁ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā antarā ca rājagaham antarā ca nāḷandam addhāna magga ppaṭipannaḥ hoti mahatā bhikkhu saṅghena saddhim pañcamattehi bhikkhu satehi
translated: At one time the Buddha was traveling along the highway between Rājagaha and Nāḷandā with a large Saṅgha of five hundred monks.

original: Suppiyopi kho paribbājako antarā ca rājagahaṁ antarā ca nāḷandaṁ addhānamaggappaṭipanno hoti saddhiṁ antevāsinā brahmadattena māṇavena.🔽Tatra sudaṁ suppiyo paribbājako anekapariyāyena buddhassa avaṇṇaṁ bhāsati, dhammassa avaṇṇaṁ bhāsati, saṅghassa avaṇṇaṁ bhāsati;
analyzed: suppiyaḥ api kho paribbājakaḥ antarā ca rājagaham antarā ca nāḷandam addhāna magga paṭipannaḥ hoti saddhim antevāsinā brahmadattena māṇavena  tatra sudam suppiyaḥ paribbājakaḥ aneka pariyāyena buddhassa avaṇṇam bhāsati dhammassa avaṇṇam bhāsati saṅghassa avaṇṇam bhāsati
translated: The wanderer Suppiya was also traveling along the same road between Rājagaha and Nāḷandā with his pupil, the young brahmin Brahmadatta.🔽There, in many ways, the wanderer Suppiya spoke in dispraise of the Buddha, the Teaching, and the Saṅgha,

original: suppiyassa pana paribbājakassa antevāsī brahmadatto māṇavo anekapariyāyena buddhassa vaṇṇaṁ bhāsati, dhammassa vaṇṇaṁ bhāsati, saṅghassa vaṇṇaṁ bhāsati.
analyzed: suppiyassa pana paribbājakassa antevāsī brahmadattaḥ māṇavaḥ aneka pariyāyena buddhassa vaṇṇam bhāsati dhammassa vaṇṇam bhāsati saṅghassa vaṇṇam bhāsati
translated: while Suppiya’s pupil, the young brahmin Brahmadatta, spoke in many ways in praise of the Buddha, the Teaching, and the Saṅgha.

original: Itiha te ubho ācariyantevāsī aññamaññassa ujuvipaccanīkavādā bhagavantaṁ piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandhā honti bhikkhusaṅghañca.
analyzed: iti ha te ubho ācariya antevāsī aññamaññassa uju vipaccanīka vādāḥ bhagavantam piṭṭhitaḥ piṭṭhitaḥ anubandhāḥ honti bhikkhu saṅghañca
translated: So the two of them, teacher and pupil, followed along behind the Buddha and the Sangha, criticizing each other.

original: Atha kho bhagavā ambalaṭṭhikāyaṁ rājāgārake ekarattivāsaṁ upagacchi saddhiṁ bhikkhusaṅghena.
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā ambalaṭṭhikāyam rājāgārake eka ratti vāsam upagacchi saddhim bhikkhu saṅghena
translated: The Buddha then stayed for one night in the royal rest house in Ambalaṭṭhikā, together with the Sangha of monks.

original: Suppiyopi kho paribbājako ambalaṭṭhikāyaṁ rājāgārake ekarattivāsaṁ upagacchi antevāsinā brahmadattena māṇavena.
analyzed: suppiyaḥ api kho paribbājakaḥ ambalaṭṭhikāyam rājāgārake eka ratti vāsam upagacchi antevāsinā brahmadattena māṇavena
translated: The wanderer Suppiya also stayed for one night in the royal rest house in Ambalaṭṭhikā, together with his pupil, the brahmin student Brahmadatta.

original: Tatrapi sudaṁ suppiyo paribbājako anekapariyāyena buddhassa avaṇṇaṁ bhāsati, dhammassa avaṇṇaṁ bhāsati, saṅghassa avaṇṇaṁ bhāsati;
analyzed: tatra api sudam suppiyaḥ paribbājakaḥ aneka pariyāyena buddhassa avaṇṇam bhāsati dhammassa avaṇṇam bhāsati saṅghassa avaṇṇam bhāsati
translated: There, too, Suppiya spoke in many ways in dispraise of the Buddha, the Teaching, and the Sangha,

original: suppiyassa pana paribbājakassa antevāsī brahmadatto māṇavo anekapariyāyena buddhassa vaṇṇaṁ bhāsati, dhammassa vaṇṇaṁ bhāsati, saṅghassa vaṇṇaṁ bhāsati.
analyzed: suppiyassa pana paribbājakassa antevāsī brahmadattaḥ māṇavaḥ aneka pariyāyena buddhassa vaṇṇam bhāsati dhammassa vaṇṇam bhāsati saṅghassa vaṇṇam bhāsati
translated: while Brahmadatta spoke in many ways in praise of them.

original: Itiha te ubho ācariyantevāsī aññamaññassa ujuvipaccanīkavādā viharanti.
analyzed: iti ha te ubho ācariya antevāsī aññamaññassa uju vipaccanīka vādāḥ viharanti
translated: So the two of them, teacher and pupil, continued to criticize each other.

original: Atha kho sambahulānaṁ bhikkhūnaṁ rattiyā paccūsasamayaṁ paccuṭṭhitānaṁ maṇḍalamāḷe sannisinnānaṁ sannipatitānaṁ ayaṁ saṅkhiyadhammo udapādi:
analyzed: atha kho sambahulānam bhikkhūnam rattiyā paccūsa samayam paccuṭṭhitānam maṇḍalamāḷe sannisinnānam sannipatitānam ayam saṅkhiya dhammaḥ udapādi
translated: and told him what had happened.

original: “acchariyaṁ, āvuso, abbhutaṁ, āvuso, yāvañcidaṁ tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena sattānaṁ nānādhimuttikatā suppaṭividitā.
analyzed: acchariyaḥ āvuso abbhutaḥ āvuso yāvat cidam tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena sattānam nānā adhimuttika tā suppaṭividitā
translated: “It’s astonishing and amazing that the Buddha, perfected and fully awakened, should know so well the diversity of beings’ dispositions.

original: Ayañhi suppiyo paribbājako anekapariyāyena buddhassa avaṇṇaṁ bhāsati, dhammassa avaṇṇaṁ bhāsati, saṅghassa avaṇṇaṁ bhāsati;
analyzed: ayam hi suppiyaḥ paribbājakaḥ aneka pariyāyena buddhassa avaṇṇam bhāsati dhammassa avaṇṇam bhāsati saṅghassa avaṇṇam bhāsati
translated: For Suppiya the wanderer disparages the Buddha, the Teaching, and the Sangha in many ways,

original: suppiyassa pana paribbājakassa antevāsī brahmadatto māṇavo anekapariyāyena buddhassa vaṇṇaṁ bhāsati, dhammassa vaṇṇaṁ bhāsati, saṅghassa vaṇṇaṁ bhāsati.
analyzed: suppiyassa pana paribbājakassa antevāsī brahmadattaḥ māṇavaḥ aneka pariyāyena buddhassa vaṇṇam bhāsati dhammassa vaṇṇam bhāsati saṅghassa vaṇṇam bhāsati
translated: while his pupil Brahmadatta the brahmin student praises them in many ways.

original: Itihame ubho ācariyantevāsī aññamaññassa ujuvipaccanīkavādā bhagavantaṁ piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandhā honti bhikkhusaṅghañcā”ti.
analyzed: ubho ācariya antevāsī aññamaññassa uju vipaccanīka vādāḥ bhagavantam piṭṭhitaḥ piṭṭhitaḥ anubandhāḥ honti bhikkhu saṅgham ca ati
translated: So these two teachers and pupils follow close behind the Buddha and the Sangha, disagreeing with each other.”

original: Atha kho bhagavā tesaṁ bhikkhūnaṁ imaṁ saṅkhiyadhammaṁ viditvā yena maṇḍalamāḷo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi. Nisajja kho bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi:
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā tesam bhikkhūnam imam saṅkhiya dhammam viditvā yena maṇḍalamāḷo tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi nisajja kho bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi
translated: Then, knowing the discussion that was taking place among the monks, the Blessed One went to the attendance hall and sat down on a seat made ready. He said to the monks,

original: “kāya nuttha, bhikkhave, etarahi kathāya sannisinnā sannipatitā, kā ca pana vo antarākathā vippakatā”ti?
analyzed: kāya nuttha bhikkhave etarahi kathāya sannisinnā sannipatitā kā ca pana vaḥ antarākathā vippakatā ati
translated: “Monks, what is your discussion now? What was your discussion that was left unfinished?”

original: Evaṁ vutte, te bhikkhū bhagavantaṁ etadavocuṁ:
analyzed: evam vutte te bhikkhū bhagavantam etat avocuḥ
translated: When this was said, the monks replied to the Blessed One,

original: “idha, bhante, amhākaṁ rattiyā paccūsasamayaṁ paccuṭṭhitānaṁ maṇḍalamāḷe sannisinnānaṁ sannipatitānaṁ ayaṁ saṅkhiyadhammo udapādi:
analyzed: idha bhante amhākam rattiyā paccūsa samayam paccuṭṭhitānam maṇḍalamāḷe sannisinnānam sannipatitānam ayam saṅkhiya dhammaḥ udapādi
translated: “Here, lord, after the meal, on returning from our alms round, we gathered in the attendance hall and were sitting together when this discussion arose:

original: ‘acchariyaṁ, āvuso, abbhutaṁ, āvuso, yāvañcidaṁ tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena sattānaṁ nānādhimuttikatā suppaṭividitā.
analyzed: acchariyaḥ āvuso abbhutaḥ āvuso yāvat cidam tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena sattānam nānā adhimuttika tā suppaṭividitā
translated: ‘It’s amazing, friends. It’s astounding, how well it has been said by the Blessed One who knows & sees, worthy & rightly self-awakened: “The inclinations of beings are known in many a way.

original: Ayañhi suppiyo paribbājako anekapariyāyena buddhassa avaṇṇaṁ bhāsati, dhammassa avaṇṇaṁ bhāsati, saṅghassa avaṇṇaṁ bhāsati;
analyzed: ayam hi suppiyaḥ paribbājakaḥ aneka pariyāyena buddhassa avaṇṇam bhāsati dhammassa avaṇṇam bhāsati saṅghassa avaṇṇam bhāsati
translated: For the wanderer Suppiya has spoken in many ways in dispraise of the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Sangha,

original: suppiyassa pana paribbājakassa antevāsī brahmadatto māṇavo anekapariyāyena buddhassa vaṇṇaṁ bhāsati, dhammassa vaṇṇaṁ bhāsati, saṅghassa vaṇṇaṁ bhāsati.
analyzed: suppiyassa pana paribbājakassa antevāsī brahmadattaḥ māṇavaḥ aneka pariyāyena buddhassa vaṇṇam bhāsati dhammassa vaṇṇam bhāsati saṅghassa vaṇṇam bhāsati
translated: while his pupil Brahmadatta has spoken in many ways in praise of the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Sangha.

original: Itihame ubho ācariyantevāsī aññamaññassa ujuvipaccanīkavādā bhagavantaṁ piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandhā honti bhikkhusaṅghañcā’ti.
analyzed: ubho ācariya antevāsī aññamaññassa uju vipaccanīka vādāḥ bhagavantam piṭṭhitaḥ piṭṭhitaḥ anubandhāḥ honti bhikkhu saṅgham ca ati
translated: So these two teachers and pupils follow right after the Blessed One and the Sangha of bhikkhus, refuting each other’s words.”

original: Ayaṁ kho no, bhante, antarākathā vippakatā, atha bhagavā anuppatto”ti.
analyzed: ayam kho naḥ bhante antarākathā vippakatā atha bhagavā anuppatto ti
translated: This was the conversation we were having, sir, when the Blessed One arrived.”

original: “Mamaṁ vā, bhikkhave, pare avaṇṇaṁ bhāseyyuṁ, dhammassa vā avaṇṇaṁ bhāseyyuṁ, saṅghassa vā avaṇṇaṁ bhāseyyuṁ, tatra tumhehi na āghāto na appaccayo na cetaso anabhiraddhi karaṇīyā.
analyzed: mamam vā bhikkhave pare avaṇṇam bhāseyyu dhammassa vā avaṇṇam bhāseyyu saṅghassa vā avaṇṇam bhāseyyu tatra tumhehi na āghātaḥ na appaccayaḥ na cetasaḥ anabhiraddhi karaṇīyā
translated: “Monks, if others speak in dispraise of me, of the Dhamma, or of the Sangha, you should not give way to resentment, aversion, or distress.

original: Mamaṁ vā, bhikkhave, pare avaṇṇaṁ bhāseyyuṁ, dhammassa vā avaṇṇaṁ bhāseyyuṁ, saṅghassa
analyzed: mamam vā bhikkhave pare avaṇṇam bhāseyyu dhammassa vā avaṇṇam bhāseyyu saṅghassa
translated: If others criticize me, the Teaching, or the Sangha,

original: vā avaṇṇaṁ bhāseyyuṁ, tatra ce tumhe assatha kupitā vā anattamanā vā, tumhaṁ yevassa tena antarāyo.
analyzed: vā avaṇṇam bhāseyyu tatra ce tumhe assatha kupitāḥ vā anatta manāḥ vā tumham yeva assa tena antarāyaḥ
translated: and you get angry or upset, that will be an obstacle for you.

original: Mamaṁ vā, bhikkhave, pare avaṇṇaṁ bhāseyyuṁ, dhammassa vā avaṇṇaṁ bhāseyyuṁ, saṅghassa🔽vā avaṇṇaṁ bhāseyyuṁ, tatra ce tumhe assatha kupitā vā anattamanā vā, api nu tumhe
analyzed: mamam vā bhikkhave pare avaṇṇam bhāseyyu dhammassa vā avaṇṇam bhāseyyu saṅghassa  vā avaṇṇam bhāseyyu tatra ce tumhe assatha kupitāḥ vā anattamanāḥ vā api nu tumhe
translated: If others criticize me, the Teaching, or the Sangha,🔽and you get angry or upset, will you be able to understand

original: paresaṁ subhāsitaṁ dubbhāsitaṁ ājāneyyāthā”ti?
analyzed: paresam su bhāsitam dubbhāsitam ājāneyyātha ati
translated: whether what they say is well spoken or badly spoken?”

original: “No hetaṁ, bhante”.
analyzed: naḥ heta bhante
translated: “No, Venerable Sir.”

original: “Mamaṁ vā, bhikkhave, pare avaṇṇaṁ bhāseyyuṁ, dhammassa vā avaṇṇaṁ bhāseyyuṁ, saṅghassa vā avaṇṇaṁ bhāseyyuṁ, tatra tumhehi abhūtaṁ abhūtato nibbeṭhetabbaṁ:
analyzed: mamam vā bhikkhave pare avaṇṇam bhāseyyu dhammassa vā avaṇṇam bhāseyyu saṅghassa vā avaṇṇam bhāseyyu tatra tumhehi abhūtam abhūtatas
translated: “If others criticize me, the Teaching, or the Sangha, you should make them understand what is untrue as being untrue,

original: ‘itipetaṁ abhūtaṁ, itipetaṁ atacchaṁ, natthi cetaṁ amhesu, na ca panetaṁ amhesu saṁvijjatī’ti.
analyzed: iti petam abhūta iti petam ataccha natthi ca itam amhesu na ca pana itam amhesu savijjati iti
translated: saying, ‘This is untrue, this is false, this is not found among us, and this is not to be found among us.’

original: Mamaṁ vā, bhikkhave, pare vaṇṇaṁ bhāseyyuṁ, dhammassa vā vaṇṇaṁ bhāseyyuṁ, saṅghassa vā vaṇṇaṁ bhāseyyuṁ, tatra tumhehi na ānando na somanassaṁ na cetaso uppilāvitattaṁ karaṇīyaṁ.
analyzed: mamam vā bhikkhave pare vaṇṇam bhāseyyu dhammassa vā vaṇṇam bhāseyyu saṅghassa vā vaṇṇam bhāseyyu tatra tumhehi na ānandaḥ na somanassam na cetasaḥ uppilāvitattam karaṇīya
translated: If others praise me, the Dhamma, or the Sangha, you shouldn’t be elated, uplifted, or thrilled.

original: Mamaṁ vā, bhikkhave, pare vaṇṇaṁ bhāseyyuṁ, dhammassa vā vaṇṇaṁ bhāseyyuṁ, saṅghassa🔽vā vaṇṇaṁ bhāseyyuṁ, tatra ce tumhe assatha ānandino sumanā uppilāvitā tumhaṁ yevassa tena antarāyo.
analyzed: mamam vā bhikkhave pare vaṇṇam bhāseyyu dhammassa vā vaṇṇam bhāseyyu saṅghassa  vā vaṇṇam bhāseyyu tatra ce tumhe assatha ānandinaḥ sumanāḥ uppilāvitā tumham yeva assa tena antarāyaḥ
translated: If you are elated, uplifted, or thrilled, you will be an obstacle to yourself.

original: Mamaṁ vā, bhikkhave, pare vaṇṇaṁ bhāseyyuṁ, dhammassa vā vaṇṇaṁ bhāseyyuṁ, saṅghassa vā vaṇṇaṁ bhāseyyuṁ, tatra tumhehi bhūtaṁ bhūtato paṭijānitabbaṁ:
analyzed: mamam vā bhikkhave pare vaṇṇam bhāseyyu dhammassa vā vaṇṇam bhāseyyu saṅghassa vā vaṇṇam bhāseyyu tatra tumhehi bhūtam bhūtataḥ paṭijānitabba
translated: If others praise me, the Dhamma, or the Sangha, you should admit what is factual as factual, saying,

original: ‘itipetaṁ bhūtaṁ, itipetaṁ tacchaṁ, atthi cetaṁ amhesu, saṁvijjati ca panetaṁ amhesū’ti.🔽2. Sīla
analyzed: iti petam bhūta iti petam tat śa atthi ca itam amhesu sa vijjati ca pana itam amhesu uti  sīla
translated: ‘In this way it’s factual, in this way it’s true, and this is found among us.’

original: 2.1. Cūḷasīla
analyzed: cūḍasīla
translated: The training rules🔽The shorter training rules

original: Appamattakaṁ kho panetaṁ, bhikkhave, oramattakaṁ sīlamattakaṁ, yena puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṁ vadamāno vadeyya.
analyzed: appamattakam kho pana ita bhikkhave oramattakam sīla mattaka yena puthujjanaḥ tathāgatassa vaṇṇam vadamānaḥ vadeyya
translated: But this is a trifling, insignificant matter, a mere observance of morality, on account of which a person might praise the Tathāgata.

original: Katamañca taṁ, bhikkhave, appamattakaṁ oramattakaṁ sīlamattakaṁ, yena puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṁ vadamāno vadeyya?
analyzed: kataman ca bhikkhave appamattakam ora mattakam sīla mattaka yena puthujjanaḥ tathāgatassa vaṇṇam vadamānaḥ vadeyya
translated: And what is that trifling, insignificant matter, a mere observance of morality, on account of which a person might praise the Tathāgata?

original: ‘Pāṇātipātaṁ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo nihitadaṇḍo, nihitasattho, lajjī, dayāpanno, sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharatī’ti—
analyzed: pāṇa atipātam pahāya pāṇa atipātā paṭivirataḥ samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ nihita daṇḍaḥ nihita satthaḥ lajjī dayā āpannaḥ sabba pāṇa bhūta hita anukampī viharati iti
translated: ‘The ascetic Gotama has given up killing living beings and abstains from killing living beings. He has given up taking what is not given and abstains from taking what is not given. He has given up sexual activity and abides with sexual abstinence. He has given up lying and abstains from lying. He has given up fermented and distilled liquors that cause heedlessness and abstains from taking them.’

original: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṁ vadamāno vadeyya.
analyzed: iti vā hi bhikkhave puthujjanaḥ tathāgatassa vaṇṇam vadamānaḥ vadeyya
translated: This is a trifling, insignificant matter, a mere observance of morality, on account of which a person might praise the Tathāgata.

original: ‘Adinnādānaṁ pahāya adinnādānā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo dinnādāyī dinnapāṭikaṅkhī, athenena sucibhūtena attanā viharatī’ti—
analyzed: a dinna ādānam pahāya a dinna ādānā paṭivirataḥ samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ dinna ādāyī dinna pāṭikaṅkhī atha enena sucibhūtena attanā viharati iti
translated: ‘The ascetic Gotama has given up taking what is not given and abstains from taking what is not given. He is content with his own possessions and does not covet the possessions of others.’

original: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṁ vadamāno vadeyya.
analyzed: iti vā hi bhikkhave puthujjanaḥ tathāgatassa vaṇṇam vadamānaḥ vadeyya
translated: This is a trifling, insignificant matter, a mere observance of morality, on account of which a person might praise the Tathāgata.

original: ‘Abrahmacariyaṁ pahāya brahmacārī samaṇo gotamo ārācārī virato methunā gāmadhammā’ti—
analyzed: a brahmacariyam pahāya brahmacārī samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ ārā cārī virataḥ methunā
translated: ‘He has given up unchastity and lives a chaste life, refraining from sexual intercourse, the common person’s practice.’

original: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṁ vadamāno vadeyya.
analyzed: iti vā hi bhikkhave puthujjanaḥ tathāgatassa vaṇṇam vadamānaḥ vadeyya
translated: In this way, monks, a fool might praise the Realized One.

original: ‘Musāvādaṁ pahāya musāvādā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo saccavādī saccasandho theto paccayiko avisaṁvādako lokassā’ti—
analyzed: musāvādam pahāya musāvādā paṭivirataḥ samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ sacca vādī sacca sandho theto paccayikaḥ a visavādakaḥ lokassa ati
translated: ‘He has given up false speech and abstains from false speech, truthful, trustworthy, reliable, no deceiver of the world.

original: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṁ vadamāno vadeyya.🔽‘Pisuṇaṁ vācaṁ pahāya pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo, ito sutvā na amutra🔽akkhātā imesaṁ bhedāya, amutra vā sutvā na imesaṁ akkhātā amūsaṁ bhedāya. Iti bhinnānaṁ
analyzed: iti vā hi bhikkhave puthujjanaḥ tathāgatassa vaṇṇam vadamānaḥ vadeyya  pisuṇam vācam pahāya pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirataḥ samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ itas sutvā na amutra  akkhātāḥ imesam bhedāya amutra vā sutvā naḥ imesam akkhātāḥ amūsam bhedāya iti

original: vā sandhātā, sahitānaṁ vā anuppadātā samaggārāmo samaggarato samagganandī samaggakaraṇiṁ vācaṁ bhāsitā’ti—

What he has heard there he does not tell here to break these people apart from those people. original: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṁ vadamāno vadeyya.

original: ‘Pharusaṁ vācaṁ pahāya pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo, yā sā vācā nelā kaṇṇasukhā pemanīyā hadayaṅgamā porī bahujanakantā bahujanamanāpā tathārūpiṁ vācaṁ bhāsitā’ti—

translated: ‘The ascetic Gotama has given up harsh speech and abstains from harsh speech. He speaks only what is gentle to the ear, pleasing to the heart, endearing, urbane, pleasing and attractive to the multitude.

original: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṁ vadamāno vadeyya.🔽‘Samphappalāpaṁ pahāya samphappalāpā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo kālavādī bhūtavādī

original: cattālīsampi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni: “amutrāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro🔽evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṁ; tatrāpāsiṁ
analyzed: cattālīsam pi savaṭṭa vivaṭṭāni amutra asim eva nāmaḥ evaṃgottaḥ eva vaṇṇo evam āhāraḥ 🔽eva sukha dukkha ppaṭisavedī evam āyu pariyanto saḥ tatas cutaḥ amutra udapādi tatra apāsi
translated: I can recollect one eon of cosmic contraction and expansion, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty eons of cosmic contraction and expansion: ‘There I had such a name, belonged to such a clan, had such an appearance. Such was my food, such my sensitivity to pleasure and pain, such the end of my life. Passing away from that state, I re-arose there. There too I had such a name, belonged to such a clan, had such an appearance. Such was my food, such my sensitivity to pleasure and pain, such the end of my life. Passing away from that state, I re-arose here.’

original: evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto,🔽so tato cuto idhūpapanno”ti. Iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarāmi.🔽Imināmahaṁ etaṁ jānāmi:
analyzed: eva nāmaḥ evaṃgotto eva vaṇṇo evam āhāro eva sukha dukkha paṭisavedī evam āyu pariyanto  saḥ tatas cutaḥ idha upapannaḥ ti iti sa ākāram sa uddesam aneka vihitam pubbenivāsam anussarāmi  etam jānāmi
translated: “There are, monks, some ascetics and brahmins who are of the doctrine of endless equivocation, who proclaim the doctrine of endless equivocation, and who explain the matter thus:

original: “yathā sassato attā ca loko ca vañjho kūṭaṭṭho esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhito, te ca sattā sandhāvanti saṁsaranti cavanti upapajjanti, atthi tveva sassatisaman”’ti.
analyzed: yathā sassataḥ attā ca loko ca vañjhaḥ kūṭaṭṭhaḥ te ca sattā sandhāvanti sasaranti cavanti upapajjanti atthi tu eva sassati samanti
translated: ‘Our speech is not to be surpassed on earth, in the heaven of the Four Great Kings, in the heaven of the Thirty-three, in the Yama heaven, in the Tusita heaven, in the heaven of the gods of re­lentless activity, in the Brahma world, or anywhere in the whole extent of the world.🔽This is the fourth case.

original: Idaṁ, bhikkhave, tatiyaṁ ṭhānaṁ, yaṁ āgamma yaṁ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā sassataṁ attānañca lokañca paññapenti.🔽Catutthe ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha sassatavādā sassataṁ attānañca lokañca paññapenti?
analyzed: idam bhikkhave tatiyam ṭhāna yam āgamma yam ārabbha eke samaṇa brāhmaṇā sassata vādā sassatam attānañca lokañca paññapenti 🔽catutthe ca bhonto samaṇa brāhmaṇā kim āgamma kim ārabbha sassata vādā sassatam attānam ca lokañca paññapenti
translated: “There are, monks, some ascetics and brahmins who are of the doctrine of eternalism, who proclaim the doctrine of eternalism, and who explain the matter thus:

original: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā takkī hoti vīmaṁsī, so takkapariyāhataṁ vīmaṁsānucaritaṁ sayaṁ paṭibhānaṁ evamāha:🔽‘sassato attā ca loko ca vañjho kūṭaṭṭho esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhito;
analyzed: idha bhikkhave ekaccaḥ samaṇaḥ vā brāhmaṇaḥ vā takkī hoti vīmasī saḥ takka pariyāhatam vīmasa anucaritam sayam paṭibhānam evam āha  sassataḥ attā ca loko ca vañjhaḥ kūṭaṭṭhaḥ esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitaḥ
translated: There is the case where a certain contemplative or brāhmaṇa is a reasoner, investigator.

original: te ca sattā sandhāvanti saṁsaranti cavanti upapajjanti, atthi tveva sassatisaman’ti.🔽Idaṁ, bhikkhave, catutthaṁ ṭhānaṁ, yaṁ āgamma yaṁ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā sassataṁ attānañca lokañca paññapenti.🔽Imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā sassataṁ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi.
analyzed: te ca sattā sandhāvanti sasaranti cavanti upapajjanti atthi tu eva sassatisamanti  idam bhikkhave catuttham ṭhāna yam āgamma yam ārabbha eke samaṇa brāhmaṇā sassata vādā sassatam attānañca lokañca paññapenti  imehi kho te bhikkhave samaṇa brāhmaṇā sassata vādā sassatam attānam ca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi
translated: Through his own insight he has realized this: ‘The self & the cosmos are eternal. This is stable, this is security, this is the goal, this is the holy life, this is the supreme truth, namely, that the self & the cosmos are eternal.’🔽This is the fourth case.🔽These are the four cases on the basis of which those contemplatives & brāhmaṇas who are eternalists declare the self & the cosmos to be eternal.🔽“Any contemplatives or brāhmaṇas who declare the self & the cosmos to be eternal do so on one or another of these four grounds. There is no other ground.

original: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā sassatavādā sassataṁ attānañca lokañca paññapenti, sabbe te imeheva catūhi vatthūhi, etesaṁ vā aññatarena; natthi ito bahiddhā.
analyzed: ye hi keci bhikkhave samaṇāḥ vā brāhmaṇāḥ vā sassata vādāḥ sassatam attānam ca lokañca paññapenti sabbe te imehi iva catūhi vatthūhi etesam vā aññatarena na atthi itas bahiddhā
translated: “Whatever contemplatives or brāhmaṇas assert the self & the cosmos to be eternal do so on one or another of these four grounds. There is no other ground.

original: Tayidaṁ, bhikkhave, tathāgato pajānāti:
analyzed: tayida bhikkhave tathāgataḥ pajānāti
translated: The Tathagata understands:

original: ‘ime diṭṭhiṭṭhānā evaṅgahitā evaṁparāmaṭṭhā evaṅgatikā bhavanti evaṁabhisamparāyā’ti,🔽tañca tathāgato pajānāti, tato ca uttaritaraṁ pajānāti; tañca pajānanaṁ na parāmasati, aparāmasato cassa paccattaññeva nibbuti viditā.
analyzed: ime diṭṭhi ṭṭhānāḥ evaṅgahitāḥ eva parāmaṭṭhāḥ evaṅgatikāḥ bhavanti eva abhisamparāyāti  tat ca tathāgataḥ pajānāti tatas ca uttaritaram pajānāti tat ca pajānanam na parāmasati a parāmasataḥ ca ssa paccattaññā eva nibbuti viditā
translated: ‘These viewpoints thus grasped and adhered to will lead to such-and-such destinations in another world.’🔽He understands this, and what is beyond it. And this understanding is not misapprehended. Through not misapprehending, the Tathagata has attained Nibbana.

original: Vedanānaṁ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṁ viditvā anupādāvimutto, bhikkhave, tathāgato.
analyzed: vedanānam samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtam viditvā an upādā vimuttaḥ bhikkhave tathāgataḥ
translated: The Tathagata, bhikkhus, is emancipated through non-clinging by having directly known and fully understood as they really are the origin, the disappearance, the gratification, the danger, and the escape in the case of the feelings.

original: Ime kho te, bhikkhave, dhammā gambhīrā duddasā duranubodhā santā paṇītā atakkāvacarā🔽nipuṇā paṇḍitavedanīyā, ye tathāgato sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti, yehi tathāgatassa
analyzed: ime kho te bhikkhave dhammā gambhīrāḥ duddasāḥ duranubodhā santā paṇītāḥ a takka avacarā  nipuṇā paṇḍita vedanīyāḥ ye tathāgataḥ sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti yehi tathāgatassa
translated: These states, bhikkhus, are deep, hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful and sublime, beyond the sphere of reasoning, subtle, comprehensible only to the wise.🔽But they have been fully awakened to by the Tathagata,

original: yathābhuccaṁ vaṇṇaṁ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṁ.
analyzed: yathābhuccam vaṇṇam sammā vadamānāḥ vadeyyu
translated: and it is concerning these that those who would rightly praise the Tathagata in accordance with reality would speak.

original: Paṭhamabhāṇavāro.🔽3.1.2. Ekaccasassatavāda
analyzed: paṭhama bhāṇavāro 🔽ekacca sas sata vāda
translated: The first section for recitation.🔽… The doctrine of partial eternalism

original: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṁ sassataṁ ekaccaṁ asassataṁ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi.
analyzed: santi bhikkhave eke samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ ekacca sassatikāḥ ekacca asassatikāḥ ekaccam sassatam ekaccam asassatam attānam ca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi
translated: “There are some ascetics and brahmins who describe the self as partly eternal and partly non-eternal, and who do so on four grounds.

original: Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṁ sassataṁ ekaccaṁ asassataṁ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi?
analyzed: te ca bhonto samaṇa brāhmaṇā kim āgamma kim ārabbha ekacca sassatikāḥ ekacca asassatikāḥ ekaccam sassatam ekaccam asassatam attānam ca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi
translated: On what grounds do they do so?

original: Hoti kho so, bhikkhave, samayo, yaṁ kadāci karahaci dīghassa addhuno accayena ayaṁ loko saṁvaṭṭati.
analyzed: hoti kho saḥ bhikkhave samayaḥ yam kadāci karahaci dīghassa addhunaḥ accayena ayam lokaḥ savaṭṭati
translated: “There comes a time, bhikkhus, sooner or later after a long period, when this world contracts.

original: Saṁvaṭṭamāne loke yebhuyyena sattā ābhassarasaṁvattanikā honti.
analyzed: sa vaṭṭamāne loke yebhuyyena sattāḥ ābhassarasavattanikāḥ honti
translated: When the world is contracting, beings are for the most part reborn in the Abhassara Brahma-world.

original: Te tattha honti manomayā pītibhakkhā sayaṁpabhā antalikkhacarā subhaṭṭhāyino, ciraṁ dīghamaddhānaṁ tiṭṭhanti.
analyzed: te tattha honti manaḥ mayāḥ pīti bhakkhāḥ saya pabhāḥ antalikkha carāḥ subha ṭṭhāyinaḥ ciram dīgham addhānam tiṭṭhanti
translated: There they dwell, mind-made, feeding on rapture, self-luminous, moving through the air, abiding in glory.

original: Hoti kho so, bhikkhave, samayo, yaṁ kadāci karahaci dīghassa addhuno accayena ayaṁ loko vivaṭṭati.
analyzed: hoti kho saḥ bhikkhave samayaḥ yam kadāci karahaci dīghassa addhunaḥ accayena ayam lokaḥ vivaṭṭati
translated: “There comes a time, sooner or later after a long period, when this world expands.

original: Vivaṭṭamāne loke suññaṁ brahmavimānaṁ pātubhavati.
analyzed: vivaṭṭamāne loke suññam brahmavimānam pātubhavati
translated: When the world is expanding, an empty divine palace appears in the base of the empty air kasiṇa.

original: Atha kho aññataro satto āyukkhayā vā puññakkhayā vā ābhassarakāyā cavitvā suññaṁ brahmavimānaṁ upapajjati.
analyzed: atha kho aññataraḥ sattaḥ āyu khayā vā puñña khayā vā ābhassara kāyā cavitvā suññam brahmavimānam upapajjati
translated: Then a certain being, with the breaking up of the body after death, is reborn in the empty divine palace.

original: So tattha hoti manomayo pītibhakkho sayampabho antalikkhacaro subhaṭṭhāyī, ciraṁ dīghamaddhānaṁ tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: saḥ tattha hoti manaḥ mayaḥ pīti bhakkho sayampabhaḥ antalikkha caraḥ subha ṭṭhāyī ciram dīgham addhānam tiṭṭhati
translated: There he is mind-made, feeding on rapture, self-luminous, moving through the air, abiding in glory. He stays like that for a very long time.

original: Tassa tattha ekakassa dīgharattaṁ nivusitattā anabhirati paritassanā uppajjati:
analyzed: tassa tattha ekakassa dīgharattam nivusita ttā an abhirati paritassanā uppajjati
translated: But then, because he has lived alone for a very long time, dissatisfaction arises in him:

original: ‘aho vata aññepi sattā itthattaṁ āgaccheyyun’ti.
analyzed: aho vata aññe pi sattāḥ itthattam āgaccheyyunti
translated: ‘Oh, if only other beings would come here!’

original: Atha aññepi sattā āyukkhayā vā puññakkhayā vā ābhassarakāyā cavitvā brahmavimānaṁ upapajjanti tassa sattassa sahabyataṁ.
analyzed: atha aññe pi sattā āyu khayā vā puñña khayā vā ābhassara kāyā cavitvā brahmavimānam upapajjanti tassa sattassa
translated: Then other beings, with the breaking up of the body after death, are reborn in the divine palace, in the companionship of that being.

original: Tepi tattha honti manomayā pītibhakkhā sayaṁpabhā antalikkhacarā subhaṭṭhāyino, ciraṁ dīghamaddhānaṁ tiṭṭhanti.
analyzed: te api tattha honti manaḥ mayāḥ pīti bhakkhāḥ saya pabhāḥ antalikkha carāḥ subha ṭṭhāyinaḥ ciram dīgham addhānam tiṭṭhanti
translated: There they too are mind-made, feeding on rapture, self-luminous, moving through the air, abiding in glory. They stay like that for a very long time.

original: Tatra, bhikkhave, yo so satto paṭhamaṁ upapanno tassa evaṁ hoti:
analyzed: tatra bhikkhave yaḥ saḥ sattaḥ paṭhamam upapannaḥ tassa evam hoti
translated: Now, bhikkhus, the being who was first reborn there thinks:

original: ‘ahamasmi brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī issaro kattā nimmātā seṭṭho sajitā vasī pitā bhūtabhabyānaṁ.
analyzed: aham asmi brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūtaḥ vasavattī issaraḥ kattā nimmātā seṭṭhaḥ sajitā vasī pitā bhūta bhabyāna
translated: ‘I am Brahmā, the Great Brahmā, the Vanquishing One, the Powerful One, the All-Seeing One, the Controller, the Lord, the Maker and Creator, the Supreme One, the Ordainer, the Father of All That Have Been and Shall Be.

original: Mayā ime sattā nimmitā.
analyzed: mayā ime sattā nimmitā
translated: These beings were created by me.

original: Taṁ kissa hetu?
analyzed: tam kim sa hetu
translated: Why is that?

original: Mamañhi pubbe etadahosi:
analyzed: maman hi pubbe etat ahosi
translated: Because I thought:

original: “aho vata aññepi sattā itthattaṁ āgaccheyyun”ti.
analyzed: aho vata aññe pi sattāḥ itthattam āgaccheyyunti
translated: “Oh, if only other beings would come to this realm!”

original: Iti mama ca manopaṇidhi, ime ca sattā itthattaṁ āgatā’ti.
analyzed: iti mama ca manaḥ upaṇidhi ime ca sattāḥ itthattam āgatā ati
translated: And so my wish has been fulfilled, and these beings have come here.”

original: Yepi te sattā pacchā upapannā, tesampi evaṁ hoti:🔽‘ayaṁ kho bhavaṁ brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī issaro kattā nimmātā seṭṭho sajitā vasī pitā bhūtabhabyānaṁ.
analyzed: ye pi te sattā pacchā upapannā tesam pi evam hoti  ayam kho bhavam brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūtaḥ vasavattī issaraḥ kattā nimmātā seṭṭhaḥ sajitā vasī pitā bhūta bhabyāna
translated: And those beings who arose later also think:

original: Iminā mayaṁ bhotā brahmunā nimmitā.
analyzed: iminā mayam bhotā brahmunā nimmitā
translated: ‘This is Brahmā, the Great Brahmā, the Vanquishing One, the Powerful One, the All-Seeing One, the Controller, the Lord, the Maker and Creator, the Supreme One, the Ordainer, the Father of All That Have Been and Shall Be.🔽We were created by him.

original: Taṁ kissa hetu?
analyzed: tam kim sa hetu
translated: Why is that?

original: Imañhi mayaṁ addasāma idha paṭhamaṁ upapannaṁ, mayaṁ panamha pacchā upapannā’ti.
analyzed: iman hi mayam addasāma idha paṭhamam upapanna mayam panamha pacchā upapannā iti
translated: Because we saw him first, and we arose later.”

original: Tatra, bhikkhave, yo so satto paṭhamaṁ upapanno, so dīghāyukataro ca hoti vaṇṇavantataro ca mahesakkhataro ca.
analyzed: tatra bhikkhave yaḥ saḥ sattaḥ paṭhamam upapanno saḥ dīghāyukataraḥ ca hoti vaṇṇavantataraḥ ca mahesakkhataraḥ ca
translated: The first being to be reborn there has a very long life, is very beautiful, and is very powerful.

original: Ye pana te sattā pacchā upapannā, te appāyukatarā ca honti dubbaṇṇatarā ca appesakkhatarā ca.
analyzed: ye pana te sattā pacchā upapannā te appāyukatarā ca honti dubbaṇṇatarā ca appesakkhatarā ca
translated: But the beings who are later reborn there have shorter lives, are less beautiful, and are less powerful.

original: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ, bhikkhave, vijjati, yaṁ aññataro satto tamhā kāyā cavitvā itthattaṁ āgacchati.
analyzed: ṭhānam kho pana ita bhikkhave vijjati yam aññataraḥ satto tamhā kāyā cavitvā itthattam āgacchati
translated: It’s possible that a certain being passes away from that host and is reborn in this world.

original: Itthattaṁ āgato samāno agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati.🔽Agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito samāno ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya
analyzed: itthattam āgataḥ samānaḥ agārasmai anagāriyam pabbajati  agārasmai anagāriyam pabbajitaḥ samānaḥ ātappam anvāya padhānam anvāya anuyogam anvāya
translated: When he has come to this world, he goes forth from the lay life to homelessness.

original: appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṁ cetosamādhiṁ phusati, yathāsamāhite
analyzed: appamādam anvāya sammāmanasikāram anvāya tathārūpam cetaḥ samādhim phusati yathā samāhite
translated: By dint of difficulty, by dint of trouble, he experiences supernormal knowledge and memory of past lives.

original: citte taṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, tato paraṁ nānussarati.
analyzed: citte tam pubbenivāsam anussarati tatas param na anussarati
translated: But he doesn’t remember any further than that.

original: So evamāha:
analyzed: sā u evam āha
translated: He says,

original: ‘yo kho so bhavaṁ brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī
analyzed: yaḥ kho saḥ bhavam brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū an abhibhūtaḥ vasavattī
translated: ‘That Blessed One, perfected one, fully awakened Buddha, who was my teacher, was a worthy one, rightly self-awakened.

original: issaro kattā nimmātā seṭṭho sajitā vasī pitā bhūtabhabyānaṁ, yena mayaṁ bhotā brahmunā
analyzed: issaraḥ kattā nimmātā seṭṭhaḥ sajitā vasī pitā bhūtabhabyāna yena mayam bhotā brahmunā
translated: He is the Lord, the Maker and Creator, the Emanci­pator and Power, the Ordainer of all things, the Father of all that has been and shall be. We were created by that Brahma.

original: nimmitā, so nicco dhuvo sassato avipariṇāmadhammo sassatisamaṁ tatheva ṭhassati.
analyzed: so niccaḥ dhuvaḥ sassataḥ a vipariṇāma dhammo sassati samam tathā iva
translated: He is permanent, stable, eternal, not subject to change, and he will remain the same just like eternity itself.

original: Ye pana mayaṁ ahumhā tena bhotā brahmunā nimmitā, te mayaṁ aniccā addhuvā appāyukā cavanadhammā itthattaṁ āgatā’ti.🔽Idaṁ, bhikkhave, paṭhamaṁ ṭhānaṁ, yaṁ āgamma yaṁ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṁ sassataṁ ekaccaṁ asassataṁ attānañca lokañca paññapenti.
analyzed: ye pana mayam ahumhā tena bhotā brahmunā nimmitā te mayam aniccāḥ addhuvāḥ appāyukā cavana dhammāḥ itthattam āgatā ati  idam bhikkhave paṭhamam ṭhāna yam āgamma yam ārabbha eke samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ ekacca sassatikāḥ ekacca asassatikāḥ ekaccam sassatam ekaccam asassatam attānam ca lokañca paññapenti
translated: But we who were created by that Brahma are impermanent, unstable, short-lived, doomed to perish. We have come to this world.’🔽This is the first case, Ananda, on account of which some ascetics and Brahmins are partly eternalists and partly non-eternalists.

original: Dutiye ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṁ sassataṁ ekaccaṁ asassataṁ attānañca lokañca paññapenti?
analyzed: dutiye ca bhonto samaṇa brāhmaṇā kim āgamma kim ārabbha ekacca sassatikāḥ ekacca asassatikāḥ ekaccam sassatam ekaccam asassatam attānam ca lokañca paññapenti
translated: And what is the second case?

original: Santi, bhikkhave, khiḍḍāpadosikā nāma devā, te ativelaṁ hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannā
analyzed: santi bhikkhave khiḍḍāpadosikāḥ nāma devā te ativelam hassa khiḍḍā rati dhamma samāpannā
translated: There are, monks, gods called ‘Fault-finders’. They spend an inordinate time in frivolous banter.

original: viharanti. Tesaṁ ativelaṁ hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannānaṁ viharataṁ sati sammussati.
analyzed: viharanti tesam ativelam hassa khiḍḍā rati dhamma samāpannānam viharatam sati sammussati
translated: They live together indulging in and enjoying bodily, verbal, and mental carelessness.🔽

original: Satiyā sammosā te devā tamhā kāyā cavanti.🔽Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ, bhikkhave, vijjati yaṁ aññataro satto tamhā kāyā cavitvā itthattaṁ āgacchati.
analyzed: satiyā sammosā te devā tamhā kāyā cavanti  ṭhānam kho pana ita bhikkhave vijjati yam aññataraḥ satto tamhā kāyā cavitvā itthattam āgacchati
translated: They spend too much time indulging in sensual pleasures.🔽When their minds are overcome by sensual lust, they fall from that plane.🔽It’s possible that a certain being, having fallen from that plane, returns to this mortal world.

original: Itthattaṁ āgato samāno agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati.🔽Agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito samāno ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya
analyzed: itthattam āgataḥ samānaḥ agārasmai anagāriyam pabbajati  agārasmai anagāriyam pabbajitaḥ samānaḥ ātappam anvāya padhānam anvāya anuyogam anvāya
translated: When he returns to this mortal world, he goes forth from the lay life to homelessness.🔽By dint of practice, development, and cultivation, he experiences an immersion of the mind that is free of placing the mind and keeping it connected.

original: appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṁ cetosamādhiṁ phusati, yathāsamāhite
analyzed: appamādam anvāya sammāmanasikāram anvāya tathārūpam cetaḥ samādhim phusati yathā samāhite
translated: When his mind is immersed like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—he extends it and comprehends the minds of other beings, other persons, having encompassed them with his own mind.🔽He understands a mind with passion as a mind with passion,

original: citte taṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, tato paraṁ nānussarati.🔽So evamāha:
analyzed: citte tam pubbenivāsam anussarati tatas param na anussarati  sā u evam āha
translated: and a mind without passion as a mind without passion.🔽He understands a mind with hate as a mind with hate,🔽and a mind without hate as a mind without hate.🔽He understands a mind with delusion as a mind with delusion,🔽and a mind without delusion as a mind without delusion.

original: ‘ye kho te bhonto devā na khiḍḍāpadosikā, te na ativelaṁ hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannā
analyzed: ye kho te bhonto devā na khiḍḍā padosikā te na ativelam hassa khiḍḍā rati dhamma samāpannā
translated: He understands a contracted mind as contracted,🔽and a distracted mind as distracted.🔽He understands an enlarged mind as enlarged,🔽and an undeveloped mind as undeveloped.🔽He understands a surpassed mind as surpassed,🔽and an unsurpassed mind as unsurpassed.🔽He understands a concentrated mind as concentrated,

original: viharanti. Tesaṁ na ativelaṁ hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannānaṁ viharataṁ sati na
analyzed: viharanti tesam na ativelam hassa khiḍḍā rati dhamma samāpannānam viharatam sati na
translated: and an unconcentrated mind as unconcentrated.🔽He understands a liberated mind as liberated,🔽and an unliberated mind as unliberated.

original: sammussati. Satiyā asammosā te devā tamhā kāyā na cavanti;
analyzed: sammussati satiyā asammosā te devā tamhā kāyā na cavanti
translated: They are not dislodged from that state by forgetfulness.

original: niccā dhuvā sassatā avipariṇāmadhammā sassatisamaṁ tatheva ṭhassanti.
analyzed: niccā dhuvā sassatā a vipariṇāma dhammā sassati samam tathā iva
translated: They are permanent, stable, eternal, not subject to change, and they will remain the same for ever and ever.

original: Ye pana mayaṁ ahumhā khiḍḍāpadosikā, te mayaṁ ativelaṁ hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannā🔽viharimhā. Tesaṁ no ativelaṁ hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannānaṁ viharataṁ sati sammussati.🔽Satiyā sammosā evaṁ mayaṁ tamhā kāyā cutā
analyzed: ye pana mayam ahumhā khiḍḍā padosikā te mayam ativelam hassa khiḍḍā rati dhamma samāpannā  viharimhā tesam no ativelam hassa khiḍḍā rati dhamma samāpannānam viharatam sati sammussati  satiyā sammosā evam mayam tamhā kāyā cutā
translated: But we who were frivolous and indulged in excessive laughter, play, and merriment🔽were dislodged from that state by forgetfulness.🔽We were dislodged from that state by forgetfulness.

original: aniccā addhuvā appāyukā cavanadhammā itthattaṁ āgatā’ti.
analyzed: aniccā addhuvā appāyukā cavana dhammā itthattam āgatā ati
translated: We are impermanent, unstable, short-lived, and subject to destruction, having come into this state of existence.’

original: Idaṁ, bhikkhave, dutiyaṁ ṭhānaṁ, yaṁ āgamma yaṁ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṁ sassataṁ ekaccaṁ asassataṁ attānañca lokañca paññapenti.
analyzed: ida bhikkhave dutiyaṃ ṭhāna yam āgamma yam ārabbha eke samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ ekacca sassatikāḥ ekacca asassatikāḥ ekaccam sassatam ekaccam asassatam attānam ca lokañca paññapenti
translated: This is the second case, Ananda, based on which some ascetics and brahmins are partly eternalists and partly non-eternalists, proclaiming the self and the world to be partly eternal and partly non-eternal.

original: Tatiye ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṁ sassataṁ ekaccaṁ asassataṁ attānañca lokañca paññapenti?
analyzed: tatiye ca bhonto samaṇa brāhmaṇā kim āgamma kim ārabbha ekacca sassatikāḥ ekacca asassatikāḥ ekaccam sassatam ekaccam asassatam attānam ca lokañca paññapenti
translated: “And what, monks, have they seen that they proclaim a doctrine of a combination of eternalism and annihilationism?

original: Santi, bhikkhave, manopadosikā nāma devā, te ativelaṁ aññamaññaṁ upanijjhāyanti.
analyzed: santi bhikkhave manopadosikā nāma devā te ativelam aññamaññam upanijjhāyanti
translated: “There are, monks, the gods called Mind-bound. They spend an excessive amount of time in mental absorption.

original: Te ativelaṁ aññamaññaṁ upanijjhāyantā aññamaññamhi cittāni padūsenti. Te aññamaññaṁ
analyzed: te ativelam aññamaññam upanijjhāyantāḥ aññamaññamhi cittāni padūsenti te aññamañña
translated: Because they spend an excessive amount of time in mental absorption, their physical being deteriorates and their minds become scattered.

original: paduṭṭhacittā kilantakāyā kilantacittā. Te devā tamhā kāyā cavanti.
analyzed: paduṭṭha cittā kilanta kāyā kilanta cittā te devā tamhā kāyā cavanti
translated: With their physical being deteriorated and their minds scattered, they fall from that plane.

original: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ, bhikkhave, vijjati yaṁ aññataro satto tamhā kāyā cavitvā itthattaṁ āgacchati.
analyzed: ṭhānam kho pana ita bhikkhave vijjati yam aññataraḥ satto tamhā kāyā cavitvā itthattam āgacchati
translated: It is possible, monks, that a certain being, having fallen from that plane, arises in this world.

original: Itthattaṁ āgato samāno agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati.
analyzed: itthattam āgataḥ samānaḥ agārasmai anagāriyam pabbajati
translated: Having arisen in this world, he goes forth from the home life into homelessness.

original: Agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito samāno ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya
analyzed: agārasmai anagāriyam pabbajitaḥ samānaḥ ātappam anvāya padhānam anvāya anuyogam anvāya
translated: Having gone forth, by means of ardour, endeavour, application, diligence, and right reflection, he attains to such a degree of mental concentration that with his mind thus concentrated he recollects his immediately preceding life, but none before that.

original: appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṁ cetosamādhiṁ phusati, yathāsamāhite
analyzed: appamādam anvāya sammāmanasikāram anvāya tathārūpam cetaḥ samādhim phusati yathā samāhite
translated: through diligence, through heedfulness, through persistence, through carefulness, he attains that kind of concentration of mind that is without thought and examination,

original: citte taṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, tato paraṁ nānussarati.
analyzed: citte tam pubbenivāsam anussarati tatas param na anussarati
translated: and recollects his manifold past abodes with their aspects and details. But he does not recollect his past lives in the Ābhassara plane.

original: So evamāha:
analyzed: sā u evam āha
translated: He says this:🔽‘Those good gods who are not corrupters of pools

original: ‘ye kho te bhonto devā na manopadosikā, te nātivelaṁ aññamaññaṁ upanijjhāyanti. Te🔽nātivelaṁ aññamaññaṁ upanijjhāyantā aññamaññamhi cittāni nappadūsenti. Te aññamaññaṁ
analyzed: ye kho te bhonto devāḥ na manopadosikā te na ativelam aññam aññam upanijjhāyanti te  na ativelam aññamaññam upanijjhāyantāḥ aññamaññamhi cittāni nappadūsenti te aññamañña
translated: do not spend too much time looking at each other.🔽They do not corrupt each other’s minds.

original: appaduṭṭhacittā akilantakāyā akilantacittā. Te devā tamhā kāyā na cavanti,
analyzed: appaduṭṭha cittā a kilanta kāyā a kilanta cittā te devā tamhā kāyāḥ na cavanti
translated: With minds that are not corrupt, with bodies that are not corrupt, with minds that are not corrupt, those gods do not fall from that plane.

original: niccā dhuvā sassatā avipariṇāmadhammā sassatisamaṁ tatheva ṭhassanti.
analyzed: niccā dhuvā sassatā a vipariṇāma dhammā sassati samam tathā iva
translated: They are permanent, stable, eternal, not subject to change, the same for ever and ever.🔽But we, who were corrupters of pools, spent too much time looking at each other.

original: Ye pana mayaṁ ahumhā manopadosikā, te mayaṁ ativelaṁ aññamaññaṁ upanijjhāyimhā. Te🔽mayaṁ ativelaṁ aññamaññaṁ upanijjhāyantā aññamaññamhi cittāni padūsimhā, te mayaṁ
analyzed: ye pana mayam ahumhā manopadosikā te mayam ativelam aññamaññam upanijjhāyimhā te 🔽mayam ativelam aññamaññam upanijjhāyantāḥ aññamaññamhi cittāni padūsimha te maya
translated: We corrupted each other’s minds.

original: aññamaññaṁ paduṭṭhacittā kilantakāyā kilantacittā. Evaṁ mayaṁ tamhā kāyā cutā
analyzed: aññam aññam paduṭṭha cittā kilanta kāyā kilanta cittā evam mayam tamhā kāyā cutā
translated: with minds corrupted by mutual hostility, with bodies worn out and minds worn out. Thus we have come to this state of existence.

original: aniccā addhuvā appāyukā cavanadhammā itthattaṁ āgatā’ti.
analyzed: aniccā addhuvā appāyukā cavana dhammā itthattam āgatā ati
translated: We are impermanent, unstable, short-lived, transitory, gone to another state.”

original: Idaṁ, bhikkhave, tatiyaṁ ṭhānaṁ, yaṁ āgamma yaṁ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṁ sassataṁ ekaccaṁ asassataṁ attānañca lokañca paññapenti.
analyzed: idam bhikkhave tatiyam ṭhāna yam āgamma yam ārabbha eke samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ ekacca sassatikāḥ ekacca asassatikāḥ ekaccam sassatam ekaccam asassatam attānam ca lokañca paññapenti
translated: This is the third case.

original: Catutthe ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṁ sassataṁ ekaccaṁ asassataṁ attānañca lokañca paññapenti?
analyzed: catutthe ca bhonto samaṇa brāhmaṇā kim āgamma kim ārabbha ekacca sassatikāḥ ekacca asassatikāḥ ekaccam sassatam ekaccam asassatam attānam ca lokañca paññapenti
translated: “And what, bhikkhus, is the fourth case?🔽Here, bhikkhus, some recluse or brahmin is a reasoner, an inquirer.

original: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā takkī hoti vīmaṁsī. So takkapariyāhataṁ vīmaṁsānucaritaṁ sayampaṭibhānaṁ evamāha:
analyzed: idha bhikkhave ekaccaḥ samaṇaḥ vā brāhmaṇaḥ vā takkī hoti vīmasī saḥ takka pariyāhatam vīmasa anucaritam sayampaṭibhānam evam āha
translated: He reasons and inquires thus:

original: ‘yaṁ kho idaṁ vuccati cakkhuṁ itipi sotaṁ itipi ghānaṁ itipi jivhā itipi kāyo itipi, ayaṁ attā anicco addhuvo asassato vipariṇāmadhammo.
analyzed: yat kho idam vuccati cakkhum iti pi sotam itipi ghānam itipi jivhā itipi kāyaḥ itipi ayam attā aniccaḥ addhuvaḥ a sassataḥ vipariṇāma dhammo
translated: ‘What is called the eye, the ear, the nose, the tongue, the body, this self is impermanent, unstable, not eternal, but subject to change.

original: Yañca kho idaṁ vuccati cittanti vā manoti vā viññāṇanti vā ayaṁ attā nicco dhuvo sassato avipariṇāmadhammo sassatisamaṁ tatheva ṭhassatī’ti.🔽Idaṁ, bhikkhave, catutthaṁ ṭhānaṁ, yaṁ āgamma yaṁ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṁ sassataṁ ekaccaṁ asassataṁ attānañca lokañca paññapenti.🔽Imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṁ sassataṁ ekaccaṁ asassataṁ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi.
analyzed: yat ca kho idam vuccati cittam ti vā manaḥ ti vā viññāṇam ti vā ayam attā niccaḥ dhuvaḥ sassataḥ a vipariṇāma dhammo sassati samam tathā iva ṭhassati iti  idam bhikkhave catuttham ṭhāna yam āgamma yam ārabbha eke samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ ekacca sassatikāḥ ekacca asassatikāḥ ekaccam sassatam ekaccam asassatam attānam ca lokañca paññapenti  imehi kho te bhikkhave samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ ekacca sassatikāḥ ekacca asassatikāḥ ekaccam sassatam ekaccam asassatam attānam ca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi
translated: But what is called mind, or thought, or consciousness, this self is permanent, stable, eternal, not subject to change, and will endure as long as eternity.’🔽This is the fourth way in which some ascetics and Brahmins proclaim a doctrine of non-eternalism.🔽These are the four ways in which these ascetics and Brahmins proclaim a doctrine of partial-eternalism and partial-non-eternalism.

original: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṁ
analyzed: ye hi keci bhikkhave samaṇāḥ vā brāhmaṇāḥ vā ekacca sassatikāḥ ekacca asassatikāḥ ekacca
translated: Any ascetics and Brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of partial-eternalism and partial-non-eternalism do so on one or other of these four grounds.

original: sassataṁ ekaccaṁ asassataṁ attānañca lokañca paññapenti, sabbe te imeheva catūhi
analyzed: sassatam ekaccam a sassatam attānam ca lokañca paññapenti sabbe te imehi iva catūhi
translated: some a finite self and world, some an infinite self and world, some a finite and infinite self and world, some neither finite nor infinite self and world.

original: vatthūhi, etesaṁ vā aññatarena; natthi ito bahiddhā.
analyzed: vatthūhi etesam vā aññatarena na atthi itas bahiddhā
translated: All those who proclaim a doctrine of a self and world,

original: Tayidaṁ, bhikkhave, tathāgato pajānāti:
analyzed: tayida bhikkhave tathāgataḥ pajānāti
translated: The Tathāgata understands:

original: ‘ime diṭṭhiṭṭhānā evaṅgahitā evaṁparāmaṭṭhā evaṅgatikā bhavanti evaṁabhisamparāyā’ti.
analyzed: ime diṭṭhi ṭṭhānāḥ evaṅgahitāḥ eva parāmaṭṭhāḥ evaṅgatikāḥ bhavanti eva abhisamparāyāti
translated: ‘These viewpoints thus grasped and adhered to will lead to such-and-such destinations in another world.’

original: Tañca tathāgato pajānāti, tato ca uttaritaraṁ pajānāti, tañca pajānanaṁ na parāmasati, aparāmasato cassa paccattaññeva nibbuti viditā.🔽Vedanānaṁ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṁ viditvā anupādāvimutto, bhikkhave, tathāgato.
analyzed: tat ca tathāgataḥ pajānāti tatas ca uttaritaram pajānāti tat ca pajānanam na parāmasati a parāmasataḥ ca ssa paccattaññā eva nibbuti viditā  vedanānam samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtam viditvā an upādā vimuttaḥ bhikkhave tathāgataḥ
translated: The Tathāgata understands this, and he understands a further escape beyond, and he does not grasp anything in the world. Not grasping anything, he is not agitated.🔽Not being agitated, he personally attains Nibbāna.

original: Ime kho te, bhikkhave, dhammā gambhīrā duddasā duranubodhā santā paṇītā atakkāvacarā
analyzed: ime kho te bhikkhave dhammā gambhīrāḥ duddasāḥ duranubodhā santā paṇītāḥ a takka avacarā
translated: These things, monks, are deep, hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful, sublime, beyond the sphere of reasoning, profound, understandable (only) by the wise.

original: nipuṇā paṇḍitavedanīyā, ye tathāgato sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti, yehi tathāgatassa
analyzed: nipuṇā paṇḍita vedanīyāḥ ye tathāgataḥ sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti yehi tathāgatassa
translated: They are not to be grasped by mere reasoning, they are to be personally experienced by the wise.

original: yathābhuccaṁ vaṇṇaṁ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṁ.🔽3.1.3. Antānantavāda🔽Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā antānantikā antānantaṁ lokassa paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi.
analyzed: yathābhuccam vaṇṇam sammā vadamānāḥ vadeyyu         santi bhikkhave eke samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ anta anantikāḥ anta anantam lokassa paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi
translated: they would be speaking truthfully about me.🔽… The view that the world is infinite🔽“There are some ascetics and brahmins who declare the world to be infinite and support the view that the world is infinite on four grounds.

original: Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha antānantikā antānantaṁ lokassa paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi?
analyzed: te ca bhonto samaṇa brāhmaṇā kim āgamma kim ārabbha anta anantikāḥ anta anantam lokassa paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi
translated: What are those four?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya🔽appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṁ cetosamādhiṁ phusati, yathāsamāhite
analyzed: idha bhikkhave ekaccaḥ samaṇaḥ vā brāhmaṇaḥ vā ātappam anvāya padhānam anvāya anuyogam anvāya  appamādam anvāya sammāmanasikāram anvāya tathārūpam cetaḥ samādhim phusati yathā samāhite
translated: Here, some ascetic or brahmin—by means of ardor, attentiveness, and constant diligence—🔽experiences various kinds of concentration, attainments, and abidings of the mind.

original: citte antasaññī lokasmiṁ viharati.
analyzed: citte anta saññī lokasmin viharati
translated: When his mind is concentrated in this way, he remains perceiving the world to be finite.

original: So evamāha:
analyzed: sā u evam āha
translated: He says this:

original: ‘antavā ayaṁ loko parivaṭumo.
analyzed: antavān ayam lokaḥ parivaṭumaḥ
translated: ‘This world is finite and bounded by a circle.

original: Taṁ kissa hetu?
analyzed: tam kim sa hetu
translated: Why is that?

original: Ahañhi ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṁ cetosamādhiṁ phusāmi, yathāsamāhite citte antasaññī lokasmiṁ viharāmi.
analyzed: aham hi ātappam anvāya padhānam anvāya anuyogam anvāya appamādam anvāya sammāmanasikāram anvāya tathārūpam cetaḥ samādhim phusāmi yathā samāhite citte anta saññī lokasmim viharāmi
translated: “I, with the destruction of the taints, have realized for myself with direct knowledge, in this very life, the taintless liberation of mind, liberation by wisdom, and having entered upon it, I dwell in it.

original: Imināmahaṁ etaṁ jānāmi:🔽“yathā antavā ayaṁ loko parivaṭumo”’ti.
analyzed: etam jānāmi  yathā ayam lokaḥ
translated: This is what I know.🔽This is what I see.

original: Idaṁ, bhikkhave, paṭhamaṁ ṭhānaṁ, yaṁ āgamma yaṁ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā antānantikā antānantaṁ lokassa paññapenti.
analyzed: idam bhikkhave paṭhamam ṭhāna yam āgamma yam ārabbha eke samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ anta anantikāḥ anta anantam lokassa paññapenti
translated: This is the first case.

original: Dutiye ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha antānantikā antānantaṁ lokassa paññapenti?🔽Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya
analyzed: dutiye ca bhonto samaṇa brāhmaṇā kim āgamma kim ārabbha anta anantikāḥ anta anantam lokassa paññapenti  idha bhikkhave ekaccaḥ samaṇaḥ vā brāhmaṇaḥ vā ātappam anvāya padhānam anvāya anuyogam anvāya
translated: “And what is the second case?

original: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā antānantikā antānantaṁ lokassa paññapenti, sabbe te imeheva catūhi vatthūhi, etesaṁ vā aññatarena; natthi ito bahiddhā.

original: Tayidaṁ, bhikkhave, tathāgato pajānāti:🔽‘ime diṭṭhiṭṭhānā evaṅgahitā evaṁparāmaṭṭhā evaṅgatikā bhavanti evaṁabhisamparāyā’ti.

original: Tañca tathāgato pajānāti, tato ca uttaritaraṁ pajānāti, tañca pajānanaṁ na parāmasati, aparāmasato cassa paccattaññeva nibbuti viditā.

original: Vedanānaṁ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṁ viditvā anupādāvimutto, bhikkhave, tathāgato.

original: Ime kho te, bhikkhave, dhammā gambhīrā duddasā duranubodhā santā paṇītā atakkāvacarā🔽nipuṇā paṇḍitavedanīyā, ye tathāgato sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti, yehi tathāgatassa
analyzed: ime kho te bhikkhave dhammā gambhīrāḥ duddasāḥ duranubodhā santā paṇītāḥ a takka avacarā  nipuṇā paṇḍita vedanīyāḥ ye tathāgataḥ sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti yehi tathāgatassa
translated: “These things, bhikkhus, are deep, hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful, sublime, beyond the sphere of reasoning, profound, understandable (only) by the wise.🔽They are not to be grasped by mere report, nor can they be apprehended by mere reasoning, except by the wise who have experienced them.

original: yathābhuccaṁ vaṇṇaṁ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṁ.

translated: They are the things that the Tathagata, having realized them by his own super-knowledge, proclaims, and about which those who would truthfully praise the Tathagata would rightly speak.

original: 3.1.4. Amarāvikkhepavāda
analyzed: amara a vikkhepa vāda

original: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā amarāvikkhepikā, tattha tattha pañhaṁ puṭṭhā samānā vācāvikkhepaṁ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṁ catūhi vatthūhi.

translated: “There are, bhikkhus, some recluses and brahmins who are Eel-Wrigglers, and when asked about this or that matter, they resort to evasive statements and wriggle like eels on four grounds.

original: Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha amarāvikkhepikā tattha tattha pañhaṁ puṭṭhā samānā vācāvikkhepaṁ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṁ catūhi vatthūhi?

translated: And on what grounds do these good recluses and brahmins resort to evasive statements and wriggle like eels when questioned?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā ‘idaṁ kusalan’ti yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti, ‘idaṁ akusalan’ti yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti.

translated: “Here, bhikkhus, some recluse or brahmin does not understand as it really is what is wholesome and what is unwholesome.

original: Tassa evaṁ hoti:
analyzed: tassa evam hoti
translated: He thinks thus:

original: ‘ahaṁ kho “idaṁ kusalan”ti yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāmi, “idaṁ akusalan”ti yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāmi.🔽Ahañce kho pana “idaṁ kusalan”ti yathābhūtaṁ appajānanto, “idaṁ akusalan”ti yathābhūtaṁ
analyzed: aham kho idam kusalanti yathābhūtam na pajānāmi idam akusalanti yathābhūtam na pajānāmi  aham ce kho pana idam kusalanti yathābhūtam appajānantaḥ idam akusalanti yathābhūta
translated: ‘I do not understand as it really is what is wholesome and what is unwholesome.

original: appajānanto, “idaṁ kusalan”ti vā byākareyyaṁ, “idaṁ akusalan”ti vā byākareyyaṁ, taṁ mamassa musā.
analyzed: a pajānantaḥ idam kusalanti vā byākareyya idam akusalanti vā byākareyya tam mamassa musā
translated: If, without understanding as it really is what is wholesome and what is unwholesome, I were to declare: “This is wholesome, this is unwholesome,” that might be a distortion in me.

original: Yaṁ mamassa musā, so mamassa vighāto.
analyzed: yam mamassa musā saḥ mamassa vighātaḥ
translated: A distortion in me would be a vexation to me.

original: Yo mamassa vighāto so mamassa antarāyo’ti.
analyzed: yaḥ mamassa vighāto saḥ mamassa antarāyo ti
translated: A vexation in me would be an obstruction to me.’🔽So, out of fear of misrepresenting, out of a sense of urgency about misrepresenting, he does not declare: ‘This is wholesome, this is unwholesome.’

original: Iti so musāvādabhayā musāvādaparijegucchā nevidaṁ kusalanti byākaroti, na panidaṁ akusalanti byākaroti, tattha tattha pañhaṁ puṭṭho samāno vācāvikkhepaṁ āpajjati amarāvikkhepaṁ:
analyzed: iti saḥ musāvāda bhayā musāvāda parijegucchā na iva idam kusalanti byākaroti na pan idam akusalanti byākaroti tattha tattha pañham puṭṭhaḥ samānaḥ vācā vikkhepam āpajjati amarā vikkhepa
translated: When asked about this or that point, he falls into oblivion and lapses into silence.

original: ‘evantipi me no; tathātipi me no; aññathātipi me no; notipi me no; no notipi me no’ti.
analyzed: evam tipi me no tathā atipi me no aññathā atipi me no no tipi me no no tipi me no ti
translated: ‘It’s not like this, it’s not like that, it’s not like this and that, it’s not that it’s not like this, it’s not that it’s not like this and that.’

original: Idaṁ, bhikkhave, paṭhamaṁ ṭhānaṁ, yaṁ āgamma yaṁ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā amarāvikkhepikā tattha tattha pañhaṁ puṭṭhā samānā vācāvikkhepaṁ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṁ.
analyzed: ida bhikkhave paṭhamam ṭhāna yam āgamma yam ārabbha eke samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ amara a vikkhepikā tattha tattha pañham puṭṭhā samānā vācā vikkhepam āpajjanti amara a vikkhepa
translated: ‘It’s not like this, it’s not like this!’ ‘It’s not like this, but it’s not not like this!’ ‘It’s not not like this, but it’s not like this!’ ‘It’s not like this, it’s not not like this, and it’s not not like this!’”🔽This is the first case.

original: Dutiye ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha amarāvikkhepikā tattha tattha pañhaṁ puṭṭhā samānā vācāvikkhepaṁ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṁ?
analyzed: dutiye ca bhonto samaṇa brāhmaṇā kim āgamma kim ārabbha amarā vikkhepikā tattha tattha pañham puṭṭhā samānā vācā vikkhepam āpajjanti amarā vikkhepa
translated: “And what’s the second way?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā ‘idaṁ kusalan’ti yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti, ‘idaṁ akusalan’ti yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave ekaccaḥ samaṇaḥ vā brāhmaṇaḥ vā idam kusalanti yathābhūtam na pajānāti idam akusalanti yathābhūtam na pajānāti
translated: There is the case where a certain contemplative or brahman does not understand as it really is what is wholesome and what is unwholesome.

original: Tassa evaṁ hoti:
analyzed: tassa evam hoti
translated: The thought occurs to him:

original: ‘ahaṁ kho “idaṁ kusalan”ti yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāmi, “idaṁ akusalan”ti yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāmi.
analyzed: aham kho idam kusalanti yathābhūtam na pajānāmi idam akusalanti yathābhūtam na pajānāmi

original: Ahañce kho pana “idaṁ kusalan”ti yathābhūtaṁ appajānanto, “idaṁ akusalan”ti yathābhūtaṁ
analyzed: aham ce kho pana idam kusalanti yathābhūtam appajānantaḥ idam akusalanti yathābhūta
translated: If, not knowing as it really is what is wholesome and what is unwholesome, I were to claim to be a teacher of the Dhamma, that would be a lie.🔽

original: appajānanto, “idaṁ kusalan”ti vā byākareyyaṁ, “idaṁ akusalan”ti vā byākareyyaṁ, tattha🔽me assa chando vā rāgo vā doso vā paṭigho vā.
analyzed: a pajānantaḥ idam kusalanti vā byākareyya idam akusalanti vā byākareyya tattha  me assa chandaḥ vā rāgaḥ vā dosaḥ vā paṭighaḥ vā
translated: If, not knowing as it really is what is wholesome and what is unwholesome, I were to explain what is wholesome and what is unwholesome,🔽then that would be a basis for me to be reproached by wise people here and now, and it would be the reason why, with the breakup of the body, after death, I would go to a bad realm of existence.

original: Yattha me assa chando vā rāgo vā doso vā paṭigho vā, taṁ mamassa upādānaṁ.
analyzed: yattha me assa chandaḥ vā rāgaḥ vā dosaḥ vā paṭighaḥ vā tam mama assa upādāna

original: Yaṁ mamassa upādānaṁ, so mamassa vighāto.🔽Yo mamassa vighāto, so mamassa antarāyo’ti.
analyzed: yam saḥ mamassa vighātaḥ  yaḥ mamassa vighāto saḥ mamassa antarāyo ti
translated: Therefore, not knowing as it really is what is wholesome and what is unwholesome, I would not explain what is wholesome and what is unwholesome.🔽If I were to explain what is wholesome and what is unwholesome, not knowing as it really is what is wholesome and what is unwholesome, then that would be a basis for me to be reproached by wise people here and now, and it would be the reason why, with the breakup of the body, after death, I would go to a bad realm of existence.🔽Therefore, not knowing as it really is what is wholesome and what is unwholesome, I would not explain what is wholesome and what is unwholesome.🔽If I were to explain what is wholesome and what is unwholesome, not knowing as it really is what is wholesome and what is unwholesome, then that would be a basis for me to be reproached by wise people here and now, and it would be the reason why, with the breakup of the body, after death, I would go to a bad realm of existence.

original: Iti so upādānabhayā upādānaparijegucchā nevidaṁ kusalanti byākaroti, na panidaṁ akusalanti byākaroti, tattha tattha pañhaṁ puṭṭho samāno vācāvikkhepaṁ āpajjati amarāvikkhepaṁ:
analyzed: iti saḥ upādāna bhayā upādāna parijegucchā na iva idam kusalanti byākaroti na pan idam akusalanti byākaroti tattha tattha pañham puṭṭhaḥ samānaḥ vācā vikkhepam āpajjati amarā vikkhepa
translated: Therefore, not knowing as it really is what is wholesome and what is unwholesome, I would not explain what is wholesome and what is unwholesome.🔽If I were to explain what is wholesome and what is unwholesome, not knowing as it really is what is wholesome and what is unwholesome, then that would be a basis for me to be reproached by wise people here and now, and it would be the reason why, with the breakup of the body, after death, I would go to a bad realm of existence.

original: ‘evantipi me no; tathātipi me no; aññathātipi me no; notipi me no; no notipi me no’ti.
analyzed: evam tipi me no tathā atipi me no aññathā atipi me no no tipi me no no tipi me no ti
translated: Therefore, not knowing as it really is what is wholesome and what is unwholesome, I would not explain what is wholesome and what is unwholesome.

original: Idaṁ, bhikkhave, dutiyaṁ ṭhānaṁ, yaṁ āgamma yaṁ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā amarāvikkhepikā tattha tattha pañhaṁ puṭṭhā samānā vācāvikkhepaṁ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṁ.
analyzed: ida bhikkhave dutiyaṃ ṭhāna yam āgamma yam ārabbha eke samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ amara a vikkhepikā tattha tattha pañham puṭṭhā samānāḥ vācā vikkhepam āpajjanti amara a vikkhepa
translated: This is the second case.

original: Tatiye ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha amarāvikkhepikā tattha tattha pañhaṁ puṭṭhā samānā vācāvikkhepaṁ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṁ?
analyzed: tatiye ca bhonto samaṇa brāhmaṇā kim āgamma kim ārabbha amarā vikkhepikā tattha tattha pañham puṭṭhā samānā vācā vikkhepam āpajjanti amarā vikkhepa
translated: “And what is the third way?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā ‘idaṁ kusalan’ti yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti, ‘idaṁ akusalan’ti yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave ekaccaḥ samaṇaḥ vā brāhmaṇaḥ vā idam kusalanti yathābhūtam na pajānāti idam akusalanti yathābhūtam na pajānāti
translated: There is the case where a certain contemplative or brāhmaṇa does not discern, as it actually is, what is skillful and unskillful.

original: Tassa evaṁ hoti:
analyzed: tassa evam hoti
translated: The thought occurs to him:

original: ‘ahaṁ kho “idaṁ kusalan”ti yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāmi, “idaṁ akusalan”ti yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāmi.
analyzed: aham kho idam kusalanti yathābhūtam na pajānāmi idam akusalanti yathābhūtam na pajānāmi
translated: ‘I do not discern, as it actually is, what is skillful and unskillful.

original: Ahañce kho pana “idaṁ kusalan”ti yathābhūtaṁ appajānanto “idaṁ akusalan”ti yathābhūtaṁ appajānanto “idaṁ kusalan”ti vā byākareyyaṁ, “idaṁ akusalan”ti vā byākareyyaṁ;
analyzed: aham ce kho pana idam kusalanti yathābhūtam appajānantaḥ idam akusalanti yathābhūtam appajānantaḥ idam kusalanti vā byākareyya idam akusalanti vā byākareyya
translated: If, not knowing and seeing as it really is, ‘This is wholesome,’ ‘This is unwholesome,’ ‘This is blamable,’ ‘This is blameless,’ ‘This is to be cultivated,’ ‘This is not to be cultivated,’ ‘This is lowly,’ ‘This is superior,’ ‘This is dark,’ or ‘This is bright,’ ‘This is good,’ or ‘This is bad,’ I were to declare, ‘This is the wholesome, this is the unwholesome,’ ‘This is the blamable, this is the blameless,’ ‘This is to be cultivated, this is not to be cultivated,’ ‘This is lowly, this is superior,’ ‘This is dark, this is bright,’ ‘This is good, this is bad,’

original: santi hi kho samaṇabrāhmaṇā paṇḍitā nipuṇā kataparappavādā vālavedhirūpā, te bhindantā maññe caranti paññāgatena diṭṭhigatāni,
analyzed: santi hi kho samaṇa brāhmaṇā paṇḍitā nipuṇā kata para ppavādā te bhindantā maññe caranti paññāgatena diṭṭhigatāni
translated: then there are wise brahmans & contemplatives who are subtle, accomplished in the doctrines of others, hair-splitters, as it were. They move about ransacking, as it were, for an opportunity to find fault in what one says.

original: te maṁ tattha samanuyuñjeyyuṁ samanugāheyyuṁ samanubhāseyyuṁ.🔽Ye maṁ tattha samanuyuñjeyyuṁ samanugāheyyuṁ samanubhāseyyuṁ, tesāhaṁ na sampāyeyyaṁ.
analyzed: te mam tattha samanuyuñjeyyum samanugāheyyum samanubhāseyyu  ye mam tattha samanuyuñjeyyum samanugāheyyum samanubhāseyyu tesāham na sampāyeyya
translated: They might cross-examine me, pressing me for details, grilling me.🔽And I might not be able to respond.

original: Yesāhaṁ na sampāyeyyaṁ, so mamassa vighāto.🔽Yo mamassa vighāto, so mamassa antarāyo’ti.
analyzed: na sampāyeyya saḥ mama assa vighāto 🔽yaḥ mamassa vighāto saḥ mamassa antarāyo ti
translated: And that would be a vexation for me.🔽And vexation is an obstruction for a monk in training.

original: Iti so anuyogabhayā anuyogaparijegucchā nevidaṁ kusalanti byākaroti, na panidaṁ akusalanti byākaroti, tattha tattha pañhaṁ puṭṭho samāno vācāvikkhepaṁ āpajjati amarāvikkhepaṁ:🔽‘evantipi me no; tathātipi me no; aññathātipi me no; notipi me no; no notipi me no’ti.
analyzed: iti saḥ anuyoga bhayā anuyoga parijegucchā na iva idam kusalanti byākaroti na pan idam akusalanti byākaroti tattha tattha pañham puṭṭhaḥ samānaḥ vācā vikkhepam āpajjati amarā vikkhepa  evam tipi me no tathā atipi me no aññathā atipi me no no tipi me no no tipi me no ti
translated: When asked about this or that point, he falls back on evasive statements, on endless equivocation:🔽‘If you ask me whether there is another world, I can’t say that there is. I can’t say that there isn’t. I can’t say that there both is and isn’t. I can’t say that there neither is nor isn’t.

original: Idaṁ, bhikkhave, tatiyaṁ ṭhānaṁ, yaṁ āgamma yaṁ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā amarāvikkhepikā tattha tattha pañhaṁ puṭṭhā samānā vācāvikkhepaṁ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṁ.
analyzed: idam bhikkhave tatiyam ṭhāna yam āgamma yam ārabbha eke samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ amara avikkhepikā tattha tattha pañham puṭṭhā samānāḥ vācā vikkhepam āpajjanti amara avikkhepa
translated: This is the third case.

original: Catutthe ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha amarāvikkhepikā tattha tattha pañhaṁ puṭṭhā samānā vācāvikkhepaṁ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṁ?
analyzed: catutthe ca bhonto samaṇa brāhmaṇā kim āgamma kim ārabbha amarā vikkhepikā tattha tattha pañham puṭṭhā samānā vācā vikkhepam āpajjanti amarā vikkhepa
translated: “And what is the fourth case?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā mando hoti momūho.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave ekaccaḥ samaṇaḥ vā brāhmaṇaḥ vā mandaḥ hoti momūhaḥ
translated: There is the case where a certain contemplative or brahman is dull & stupid.

original: So mandattā momūhattā tattha tattha pañhaṁ puṭṭho samāno vācāvikkhepaṁ āpajjati amarāvikkhepaṁ:
analyzed: so manda ttā momūha ttā tattha tattha pañham puṭṭhaḥ samānaḥ vācā vikkhepam āpajjati amarā vikkhepa
translated: Being confused and muddle-headed, when asked such questions, he falls into confusion and is lost for the right answer.

original: ‘atthi paro loko’ti iti ce maṁ pucchasi, ‘atthi paro loko’ti iti ce me assa, ‘atthi paro loko’ti iti te naṁ byākareyyaṁ,
analyzed: atthi paraḥ loko ti iti ce mam pucchasi atthi paraḥ loko ti iti ce me assa atthi paraḥ loko ti iti te nam byākareyya
translated: If you ask me if there is a world beyond, and if that’s what I think, I’d say there is.

original: ‘evantipi me no, tathātipi me no, aññathātipi me no, notipi me no, no notipi me no’ti.
analyzed: evam tipi me no tathā atipi me no aññathā atipi me no no tipi me no no tipi me no ti
translated: But I don’t say, ‘It’s like this,’ or ‘It’s like that,’ or ‘It’s otherwise,’ or ‘It’s not so,’ or ‘It’s not not so.’

original: ‘Natthi paro loko …pe…🔽‘atthi ca natthi ca paro loko …pe…
analyzed: natthi paraḥ loko pe  atthi ca na atthi ca paraḥ lokaḥ pe
translated: ‘There is no world beyond …🔽‘There both is and is not a world beyond …

original: ‘nevatthi na natthi paro loko …pe…
analyzed: na iva atthi na natthi paraḥ lokaḥ pe
translated: ‘There is neither a world beyond nor not …

original: ‘atthi sattā opapātikā …pe…
analyzed: atthi sattā opapātikā pe
translated: ‘There are beings who are spontaneously reborn …

original: ‘natthi sattā opapātikā …pe…🔽‘atthi ca natthi ca sattā opapātikā …pe…
analyzed: natthi sattā opapātikā pe  atthi ca natthi ca sattā opapātikā pe
translated: ‘There are no beings who are spontaneously reborn …🔽‘There both are and are not beings who are spontaneously reborn …

original: ‘nevatthi na natthi sattā opapātikā …pe…
analyzed: na iva atthi na natthi sattāḥ opapātikāḥ pe

analyzed: atthi su kata dukkaṭānam kammānam phalam vipākaḥ pe

original: ‘natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko …pe…
analyzed: natthi su kata dukkaṭānam kammānam phalam vipākaḥ pe
translated: ‘There are no skillful and unskillful deeds and the results of skillful and unskillful deeds …

original: ‘atthi ca natthi ca sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko …pe…
analyzed: atthi ca natthi ca su kata dukkaṭānam kammānam phalam vipākaḥ pe

original: ‘nevatthi na natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko …pe…
analyzed: na iva atthi na natthi su kata dukkaṭānam kammānam phalam vipākaḥ pe
translated: ‘There is no result and ripening of good and bad actions …

original: ‘hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā …pe…
analyzed: hoti tathāgataḥ param maraṇā
translated: ‘A Realized One exists after death …

original: ‘na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā …pe…
analyzed: na hoti tathāgataḥ param maraṇā pe
translated: ‘A Realized One does not exist after death …🔽‘A Realized One both exists and does not exist after death …

original: ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā …pe…
analyzed: hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgataḥ param maraṇā pe
translated: ‘A Realized One neither exists nor does not exist after death.’🔽If you ask me this, I would answer:

analyzed: na iva hoti na na hoti tathāgataḥ param iti ce mama pucchasi na iva hoti na
translated: ‘A Realized One neither exists nor does not exist after death.’🔽If you ask me this, I would answer:

analyzed: na hoti tathāgato param iti ce me assa na iva hoti na na hoti tathāgato  param iti te nam byākareyya
translated: ‘A Realized One neither exists nor does not exist after death.’🔽‘It’s not so, sir. It’s not so, Blessed One.’

original: ‘evantipi me no, tathātipi me no, aññathātipi me no, notipi me no, no notipi me no’ti.
analyzed: evam tipi me no tathā atipi me no aññathā atipi me no no tipi me no no tipi me no ti
translated: ‘It’s not so, sir. It’s not so, Blessed One.’

translated: This is the fourth instance.🔽These are the four instances on account of which certain ascetics and brahmins are expounders of non-causality and non-conditioning, and proclaim the world to be uncaused and unconditioned.🔽“Whatever ascetics and brahmins are expounders of non-causality and non-conditioning, and proclaim the world to be uncaused and unconditioned, all of them do so on these four grounds.🔽Outside of these there is none.

analyzed: imehi kho te bhikkhave samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ amara avikkhepikā tattha tattha pañham puṭṭhā samānāḥ vācā vikkhepam āpajjanti amara avikkhepam catūhi vatthūhi  ye hi keci bhikkhave samaṇāḥ vā brāhmaṇāḥ vā tattha tattha
translated: This…🔽is the first instance.🔽… are expounders of non-causality and non-conditioning, and proclaim the world to be uncaused and unconditioned, all of them do so on these four grounds.🔽Outside of these there is none.
