original: yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṁ vaṇṇaṁ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṁ.🔽3.1.5. Adhiccasamuppannavāda
analyzed: ye hi tathāgatassa yathābhuccam vaṇṇam sammā vadamānāḥ vadeyyu 🔽adhicca samuppanna vāda
translated: … are expounders of non-causality and non-conditioning, and proclaim the world to be uncaused and unconditioned, all of them do so on these

original: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā adhiccasamuppannikā adhiccasamuppannaṁ attānañca lokañca paññapenti dvīhi vatthūhi.
analyzed: santi bhikkhave eke samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ adhiccasamuppannikāḥ adhiccasamuppannam attānam ca lokañca paññapenti dvīhi vatthūhi
translated: There are some ascetics and brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of chance, and assert a self and the world to be produced by chance on two grounds.

original: Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha adhiccasamuppannikā adhiccasamuppannaṁ attānañca lokañca paññapenti dvīhi vatthūhi?
analyzed: te ca bhonto samaṇa brāhmaṇā kim āgamma kim ārabbha adhiccasamuppannikāḥ adhiccasamuppannam attānam ca lokañca paññapenti dvīhi vatthūhi
translated: And on what grounds do they do so?

original: Santi, bhikkhave, asaññasattā nāma devā.
analyzed: santi bhikkhave asaññasattāḥ nāma devāḥ
translated: There are, monks, the gods called ‘Life-Span Infinite’.

original: Saññuppādā ca pana te devā tamhā kāyā cavanti.
analyzed: saññuppādā ca pana te devā tamhā kāyā cavanti
translated: And when the perception of those gods fails, they fall from that plane.

original: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ, bhikkhave, vijjati, yaṁ aññataro satto tamhā kāyā cavitvā itthattaṁ āgacchati.
analyzed: ṭhānam kho pana ita bhikkhave vijjati yam aññataraḥ satto tamhā kāyā cavitvā itthattam āgacchati
translated: It is possible, monks, that a certain being, having fallen from that plane, comes to this world.

original: Itthattaṁ āgato samāno agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati.
analyzed: itthattam āgataḥ samānaḥ agārasmai anagāriyam pabbajati
translated: Having come to this world, he goes forth from the home life into homelessness.

original: Agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito samāno ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya🔽appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṁ cetosamādhiṁ phusati, yathāsamāhite
analyzed: agārasmai anagāriyam pabbajitaḥ samānaḥ ātappam anvāya padhānam anvāya anuyogam anvāya 🔽appamādam anvāya sammāmanasikāram anvāya tathārūpam cetaḥ samādhim phusati yathā samāhite
translated: And having gone forth, by means of ardour, endeavour, application, diligence, and right reflection,🔽he attains to such a degree of mental concentration that he thereby recalls his last existence but is not able to recall any further.

original: citte saññuppādaṁ anussarati, tato paraṁ nānussarati.
analyzed: citte saññuppādam anussarati tatas param na anussarati
translated: he remembers the arising of perception in the mind, but nothing before that.

original: So evamāha:
analyzed: sā u evam āha
translated: He says this:

original: ‘adhiccasamuppanno attā ca loko ca.
analyzed: adhicca samuppannaḥ attā ca loko ca
translated: ‘The self and the world are caused by a creative act.

original: Taṁ kissa hetu?
analyzed: tam kim sa hetu
translated: Why is that?

original: Ahañhi pubbe nāhosiṁ, somhi etarahi ahutvā santatāya pariṇato’ti.
analyzed: aham hi pubbe na ahosi somhi etarahi a hutvā santatāya pariṇataḥ ti
translated: Because previously I did not exist, and now I exist. Having not been, I have come to be.’

original: Idaṁ, bhikkhave, paṭhamaṁ ṭhānaṁ, yaṁ āgamma yaṁ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā adhiccasamuppannikā adhiccasamuppannaṁ attānañca lokañca paññapenti.
analyzed: idam bhikkhave paṭhamam ṭhāna yam āgamma yam ārabbha eke samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ adhiccasamuppannikāḥ adhiccasamuppannam attānañca lokañca paññapenti
translated: This is the first case.

original: Dutiye ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha adhiccasamuppannikā adhiccasamuppannaṁ attānañca lokañca paññapenti?
analyzed: dutiye ca bhonto samaṇa brāhmaṇā kim āgamma kim ārabbha adhiccasamuppannikāḥ adhiccasamuppannam attānam ca lokañca paññapenti
translated: “And what is the second way?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā takkī hoti vīmaṁsī.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave ekaccaḥ samaṇaḥ vā brāhmaṇaḥ vā takkī hoti vīmasī
translated: Here, bhikkhus, a certain contemplative or brahman is a reasoner.

original: So takkapariyāhataṁ vīmaṁsānucaritaṁ sayampaṭibhānaṁ evamāha:
analyzed: saḥ evam āha
translated: Reasoning in various ways, he arrives at the conclusion:

original: ‘adhiccasamuppanno attā ca loko cā’ti.
analyzed: adhicca samuppannaḥ attā ca loko ca ati
translated: ‘The self and the world are caused by a creative act.’

original: Idaṁ, bhikkhave, dutiyaṁ ṭhānaṁ, yaṁ āgamma yaṁ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā adhiccasamuppannikā adhiccasamuppannaṁ attānañca lokañca paññapenti.
analyzed: idam bhikkhave dutiyaṃ ṭhāna yam āgamma yam ārabbha eke samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ adhiccasamuppannikāḥ adhiccasamuppannam attānañca lokañca paññapenti
translated: This is the second instance.

original: Imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā adhiccasamuppannikā adhiccasamuppannaṁ attānañca lokañca paññapenti dvīhi vatthūhi.🔽Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā adhiccasamuppannikā adhiccasamuppannaṁ
analyzed: imehi kho te bhikkhave samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ adhiccasamuppannikāḥ adhiccasamuppannam attānam ca lokañca paññapenti dvīhi vatthūhi  ye hi keci bhikkhave samaṇāḥ vā brāhmaṇāḥ vā adhiccasamuppannikāḥ adhiccasamuppanna
translated: “These are the two instances on account of which those ascetics and brahmins who are Chance Originationists and proclaim the self and the world to be chance-originated proclaim this.

original: attānañca lokañca paññapenti, sabbe te imeheva dvīhi vatthūhi, etesaṁ vā aññatarena,
analyzed: attānañca lokañca paññapenti sabbe te imehi iva dvīhi vatthūhi etesam vā aññatarena
translated: “Any ascetics and brahmins whatever who are Chance Originationists and proclaim the self and the world to be chance-originated do so on one or other of these two instances.

original: natthi ito bahiddhā …
analyzed: na atthi itas bahiddhā
translated: Outside of these there is none.🔽This won’t be for their long-term harm, misfortune, and discomfort.

original: pe…
analyzed: pe

original: yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṁ vaṇṇaṁ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṁ.
analyzed: ye hi tathāgatassa yathābhuccam vaṇṇam sammā vadamānāḥ vadeyyu
translated: they would speak in accordance with the truth.

original: Imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā pubbantakappikā pubbantānudiṭṭhino pubbantaṁ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti aṭṭhārasahi vatthūhi.
analyzed: imehi kho te bhikkhave samaṇa brāhmaṇā pubbanta kappikā pubbanta anudiṭṭhino pubbantam ārabbha aneka vihitāni adhimutti padāni abhivadanti aṭṭhārasahi vatthūhi
translated: “These are the eighteen instances on account of which those ascetics and brahmins who are speculators about the past and hold settled views about the past proclaim various conceptual theorems referring to the past.

original: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā pubbantakappikā pubbantānudiṭṭhino pubbantamārabbha
analyzed: ye hi keci bhikkhave samaṇāḥ vā brāhmaṇāḥ vā pubbanta kappikā pubbanta anudiṭṭhinaḥ pubbantam ārabbha
translated: “Any contemplatives or brahmans who are speculators about the past, who are advocates of the theory of the past, and who are of one or another of the views based on the past—

original: anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti, sabbe te imeheva aṭṭhārasahi vatthūhi,
analyzed: aneka vihitāni adhimutti padāni abhivadanti sabbe te imehi eva aṭṭhārasahi vatthūhi
translated: Whatever ascetics and brahmins are speculators about the past, and assert various speculative views about the past, all of them do so on the basis of these eighteen modes of спесulation.

original: etesaṁ vā aññatarena, natthi ito bahiddhā.
analyzed: etesam vai aññatarena na atthi itas bahiddhā
translated: Outside of these there is none.

original: Tayidaṁ, bhikkhave, tathāgato pajānāti:
analyzed: tayida bhikkhave tathāgataḥ pajānāti
translated: The Tathagata understands this.

original: ‘ime diṭṭhiṭṭhānā evaṅgahitā evaṁparāmaṭṭhā evaṅgatikā bhavanti evaṁabhisamparāyā’ti.🔽Tañca tathāgato pajānāti, tato ca uttaritaraṁ pajānāti, tañca pajānanaṁ na parāmasati, aparāmasato cassa paccattaññeva nibbuti viditā.
analyzed: ime diṭṭhi ṭṭhānāḥ evaṅgahitāḥ eva parāmaṭṭhāḥ evaṅgatikāḥ bhavanti eva abhisamparāyāti  tat ca tathāgataḥ pajānāti tatas ca uttaritaram pajānāti tat ca pajānanam na parāmasati a parāmasataḥ ca ssa paccattaññā eva nibbuti viditā
translated: And he understands: ‘These standpoints, thus assumed and thus misapprehended, lead to such a future destination, to such a state in the world beyond.🔽’ He understands as well what transcends this, yet even that understanding he does not misapprehend. Since he is not misapprehending, the Tathagata has realized within himself the unsurpassed destruction of suffering.

original: Vedanānaṁ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṁ viditvā anupādāvimutto, bhikkhave, tathāgato.
analyzed: vedanānam samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtam viditvā an upādā vimuttaḥ bhikkhave tathāgataḥ
translated: The Tathagata has understood as they really are the origin and passing away, the gratification, danger, and escape in the case of these feelings.🔽He is free from craving for the destruction of suffering.

original: Ime kho te, bhikkhave, dhammā gambhīrā duddasā duranubodhā santā paṇītā atakkāvacarā
analyzed: ime kho te bhikkhave dhammā gambhīrāḥ duddasāḥ duranubodhā santā paṇītāḥ a takka avacarā
translated: These things, bhikkhus, are deep, difficult to see, difficult to understand, peaceful and sublime, beyond the sphere of reasoning, subtle, comprehensible only to the wise.

original: nipuṇā paṇḍitavedanīyā, ye tathāgato sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti, yehi tathāgatassa
analyzed: nipuṇā paṇḍita vedanīyāḥ ye tathāgataḥ sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti yehi tathāgatassa
translated: They are subtle, hard to see, and only can be known by the wise. The Tathāgata has realized them by direct knowledge and makes them known to others.

original: yathābhuccaṁ vaṇṇaṁ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṁ.🔽Dutiyabhāṇavāro.
analyzed: yathābhuccam vaṇṇam sammā vadamānāḥ vadeyyu  dutiya bhāṇa vāraḥ
translated: Those who speak in accordance with the Teacher’s teachings are speaking correctly, not falsely.🔽The second section for recitation.

original: 3.2. Aparantakappika
analyzed: aparantakappika
translated: The future

original: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā aparantakappikā aparantānudiṭṭhino, aparantaṁ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti catucattārīsāya vatthūhi.
analyzed: santi bhikkhave eke samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ aparanta kappikāḥ aparanta anudiṭṭhinaḥ aparantam ārabbha aneka vihitāni adhimutti padāni abhivadanti catucattārīsāya vatthūhi
translated: “There are some ascetics and brahmins who are speculators about the future, who proclaim the future, and assert various doctrinal propositions about the future on forty-four grounds.

original: Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha aparantakappikā aparantānudiṭṭhino aparantaṁ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti catucattārīsāya vatthūhi?
analyzed: te ca bhonto samaṇa brāhmaṇā kim āgamma kim ārabbha aparanta kappikāḥ aparanta anudiṭṭhinaḥ aparantam ārabbha aneka vihitāni adhimutti padāni abhivadanti catucattārīsāya vatthūhi
translated: And on the basis of what do they do so?

original: 3.2.1. Saññīvāda
analyzed: saññīvāda
translated: ... The doctrine of perception

original: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā saññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṁ saññiṁ attānaṁ paññapenti soḷasahi vatthūhi.
analyzed: santi bhikkhave eke samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ uddhamāghātanikā saññīvādāḥ uddhamāghātanam saññim attānam paññapenti soḷasahi vatthūhi
translated: “There are some ascetics and brahmins who are speculators about the future, who proclaim the future, and assert various doctrinal propositions about the future on sixteen grounds.

original: Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha uddhamāghātanikā saññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṁ saññiṁ attānaṁ paññapenti soḷasahi vatthūhi?
analyzed: te ca bhonto samaṇa brāhmaṇā kim āgamma kim ārabbha uddhamāghātanikā saññīvādā uddhamāghātanam saññim attānam paññapenti soḷasahi vatthūhi
translated: And on the basis of what do they do so?🔽They assert that after death the self is percipient and possesses form, is healthy, and exists separately, on sixteen grounds.

original: ‘Rūpī attā hoti arogo paraṁ maraṇā saññī’ti naṁ paññapenti.🔽‘Arūpī attā hoti arogo paraṁ maraṇā saññī’ti naṁ paññapenti.🔽‘Rūpī ca arūpī ca attā hoti …pe….
analyzed: rūpī attā hoti arogo param maraṇā saññī iti nam paññapenti  arūpī attā hoti arogo param maraṇā saññī iti nam paññapenti  rūpī ca arūpī ca attā hoti pe
translated: They assert that after death the self is percipient and formless, is healthy, and exists separately, on sixteen grounds.🔽They assert that after death the self is percipient and both possesses form and is formless, is healthy, and exists separately, on sixteen grounds.🔽They assert that after death the self is percipient and neither possesses form nor is formless, is healthy, and exists separately, on sixteen grounds.

original: ‘Nevarūpī nārūpī attā hoti ….
analyzed: nevarūpī na arūpī attā hoti
translated: They assert that after death the self is percipient and has an end, is healthy, and exists separately, on sixteen grounds.

original: ‘Antavā attā hoti ….🔽‘Anantavā attā hoti ….🔽‘Antavā ca anantavā ca attā hoti ….
analyzed: antavān attā hoti  anantavā attā hoti  antavā ca anantavā ca attā hoti
translated: They assert that after death the self is percipient and is endless, is healthy, and exists separately, on sixteen grounds.🔽They assert that after death the self is percipient and both has an end and is endless, is healthy, and exists separately, on sixteen grounds.

original: ‘Nevantavā nānantavā attā hoti ….🔽‘Ekattasaññī attā hoti ….🔽‘Nānattasaññī attā hoti ….
analyzed: na ivantavāḥ na anantavāḥ attā hoti  ekatta saññī attā hoti  nānatta saññī attā hoti
translated: They assert that after death the self is percipient and neither has an end nor is endless, is healthy, and exists separately, on sixteen grounds.🔽They assert that after death the self is percipient and has a single perception, is healthy, and exists separately, on sixteen grounds.

original: ‘Parittasaññī attā hoti ….
analyzed: paritta saññī attā hoti
translated: They assert that after death the self is percipient and has multiple perceptions, is healthy, and exists separately, on sixteen grounds.🔽They assert that after death the self is percipient and has limited perception, is healthy, and exists separately, on sixteen grounds.

original: ‘Appamāṇasaññī attā hoti ….🔽‘Ekantasukhī attā hoti ….
analyzed: appamāṇa saññī attā hoti  ekanta sukhī attā hoti
translated: They assert that after death the self is percipient and has immeasurable perception, is healthy, and exists separately, on sixteen grounds.🔽They assert that after death the self is percipient and is exclusively happy, is healthy, and exists separately, on sixteen grounds.

original: ‘Ekantadukkhī attā hoti ….🔽‘Sukhadukkhī attā hoti ….
analyzed: ekanta dukkhī attā hoti  sukha dukkhī attā hoti
translated: They assert that after death the self is percipient and is exclusively miserable, is healthy, and exists separately, on sixteen grounds.🔽They assert that after death the self is percipient and is both happy and miserable, is healthy, and exists separately, on sixteen grounds.

original: ‘Adukkhamasukhī attā hoti arogo paraṁ maraṇā saññī’ti naṁ paññapenti.
analyzed: adukkham asukhī attā hoti arogaḥ param maraṇā saññī iti nam paññapenti
translated: They assert that after death the self is percipient and is neither happy nor miserable, is healthy, and exists separately, on sixteen grounds.

original: Imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā saññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṁ saññiṁ attānaṁ paññapenti soḷasahi vatthūhi.🔽Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā uddhamāghātanikā saññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṁ
analyzed: imehi kho te bhikkhave samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ uddhamāghātanikā saññīvādāḥ uddhamāghātanam saññim attānam paññapenti soḷasahi vatthūhi  ye hi keci bhikkhave samaṇāḥ vā brāhmaṇāḥ vā uddhamāghātanikā saññīvādāḥ uddhamāghātana
translated: These are the sixteen ways in which those ascetics and brahmins who are Extraplanetaries and proclaimers of a doctrine of consciousness after death assert a self that is conscious after death.

original: saññiṁ attānaṁ paññapenti, sabbe te imeheva soḷasahi vatthūhi, etesaṁ vā aññatarena,🔽natthi ito bahiddhā …
analyzed: saññim attānam paññapenti sabbe te imehi iva soḷasahi vatthūhi etesam vā aññatarena  na atthi itas bahiddhā
translated: “Any ascetics and brahmins who are Extraplanetaries and proclaimers of a doctrine of consciousness after death assert a self that is conscious after death in any way, all of them do so on these sixteen grounds.

original: pe…
analyzed: pe
translated: Outside of these there is none.

original: yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṁ vaṇṇaṁ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṁ.
analyzed: ye hi tathāgatassa yathābhuccam vaṇṇam sammā vadamānāḥ vadeyyu
translated: This doctrinal point was well proclaimed by the Blessed One, the Arahant, the Perfectly Enlightened One.🔽… who speak in accordance with the Dhamma.

original: 3.2.2. Asaññīvāda
analyzed: asaññīvāda
translated: … Non-percipient

original: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā asaññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṁ asaññiṁ attānaṁ paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi.
analyzed: santi bhikkhave eke samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ uddhamāghātanikāḥ asaññī vādāḥ uddhamāghātanam asaññim attānam paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi
translated: “There are, monks, some ascetics and brahmins who are Extraplanetaries and proclaimers of a doctrine of non-percipient immortality, who assert a self that is non-percipient and immortal in eight ways.

original: Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha uddhamāghātanikā asaññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṁ asaññiṁ attānaṁ paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi?
analyzed: te ca bhonto samaṇa brāhmaṇā kim āgamma kim ārabbha uddhamāghātanikāḥ asaññī vādāḥ uddhamāghātanam asaññim attānam paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi
translated: And on what grounds do they do so?

original: ‘Rūpī attā hoti arogo paraṁ maraṇā asaññī’ti naṁ paññapenti.
analyzed: rūpī attā hoti arogo param maraṇā asaññī iti nam paññapenti
translated: ‘The self is formless and, after death, is non-percipient and healthy.’

original: ‘Arūpī attā hoti arogo paraṁ maraṇā asaññī’ti naṁ paññapenti.
analyzed: arūpī attā hoti arogo param maraṇā asaññī iti nam paññapenti
translated: ‘The self is formless and, after death, is percipient and healthy.’

original: ‘Rūpī ca arūpī ca attā hoti …pe….
analyzed: rūpī ca arūpī ca attā hoti pe
translated: ‘The self is both formed and formless …

original: ‘Nevarūpī nārūpī attā hoti ….
analyzed: nevarūpī na arūpī attā hoti
translated: ‘The self is neither formed nor formless …

original: ‘Antavā attā hoti ….
analyzed: antavān attā hoti
translated: ‘The self is finite …

original: ‘Anantavā attā hoti ….
analyzed: anantavā attā hoti
translated: ‘The self is infinite …

original: ‘Antavā ca anantavā ca attā hoti ….
analyzed: antavā ca anantavā ca attā hoti
translated: ‘The self is both finite and infinite …

original: ‘Nevantavā nānantavā attā hoti arogo paraṁ maraṇā asaññī’ti naṁ paññapenti.
analyzed: na ivantavā na anantavā attā hoti arogo param maraṇā asaññī iti nam paññapenti
translated: ‘The self is neither finite nor infinite and, after death, is non-percipient and healthy.’

original: Imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā asaññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṁ asaññiṁ attānaṁ paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi.
analyzed: imehi kho te bhikkhave samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ uddhamāghātanikāḥ asaññī vādāḥ uddhamāghātanam asaññim attānam paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi
translated: These are the eight ways.

original: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā uddhamāghātanikā asaññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṁ🔽asaññiṁ attānaṁ paññapenti, sabbe te imeheva aṭṭhahi vatthūhi, etesaṁ vā aññatarena,
analyzed: ye hi keci bhikkhave samaṇāḥ vā brāhmaṇāḥ vā uddhamāghātanikāḥ asaññī vādāḥ uddhamāghātana  asaññim attānam paññapenti sabbe te imehi iva aṭṭhahi vatthūhi etesam vā aññatarena
translated: Any ascetics or brahmins who declare a view of the self that is non-percipient after death,🔽all of them do so on these eight grounds. There is no ninth ground.

original: natthi ito bahiddhā …
analyzed: na atthi itas bahiddhā
translated: These are a fact. Anything else is wrong.

original: pe…
analyzed: pe

original: yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṁ vaṇṇaṁ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṁ.🔽3.2.3. Nevasaññīnāsaññīvāda
analyzed: ye hi tathāgatassa yathābhuccam vaṇṇam sammā vadamānāḥ vadeyyu  na ivasaññī nāsaññī vāda
translated: They speak in accordance with the truth, not falsely.🔽… Those who declare a view about a non-percipient & non-non-percipient self after death

original: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā nevasaññīnāsaññīvādā, uddhamāghātanaṁ nevasaññīnāsaññiṁ attānaṁ paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi.
analyzed: santi bhikkhave eke samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ uddhamāghātanikāḥ nevasaññī nāsaññī vādāḥ uddhamāghātanam nevasaññī nāsaññim attānam paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi
translated: “Monks, there are some contemplatives & brahmans who declare a view about a non-percipient & non-non-percipient self after death based on eight grounds.

original: Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha uddhamāghātanikā nevasaññīnāsaññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṁ nevasaññīnāsaññiṁ attānaṁ paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi?
analyzed: te ca bhonto samaṇa brāhmaṇā kim āgamma kim ārabbha uddham āghātanikāḥ nevasaññī nāsaññī vādāḥ uddham āghātanam nevasaññī nāsaññim attānam paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi
translated: And on what grounds do they do so?

original: ‘Rūpī attā hoti arogo paraṁ maraṇā nevasaññīnāsaññī’ti naṁ paññapenti.🔽‘Arūpī attā hoti …pe….🔽‘Rūpī ca arūpī ca attā hoti ….🔽‘Nevarūpī nārūpī attā hoti ….
analyzed: rūpī attā hoti arogo param maraṇā nevasaññī na asaññī iti nam paññapenti  arūpī attā hoti pe  rūpī ca arūpī ca attā hoti  nevarūpī na arūpī attā hoti
translated: “There are some contemplatives & brahmans who declare that the self is percipient, formless, & unimpaired after death, describing it as non-percipient & non-non-percipient.🔽“There are some contemplatives & brahmans who declare that the self is formless, percipient, & unimpaired after death, describing it as non-percipient & non-non-percipient.🔽“There are some contemplatives & brahmans who declare that the self is both percipient & formless, & unimpaired after death, describing it as non-percipient & non-non-percipient.

original: ‘Antavā attā hoti ….🔽‘Anantavā attā hoti ….
analyzed: antavān attā hoti  anantavā attā hoti
translated: “There are some contemplatives & brahmans who declare that the self is neither percipient nor formless, & unimpaired after death, describing it as non-percipient & non-non-percipient.🔽“There are some contemplatives & brahmans who declare that the self is finite, describing it as non-percipient & non-non-percipient.

original: ‘Antavā ca anantavā ca attā hoti ….
analyzed: antavā ca anantavā ca attā hoti
translated: “There are some contemplatives & brahmans who declare that the self is infinite, describing it as non-percipient & non-non-percipient.🔽“There are some contemplatives & brahmans who declare that the self is both finite & infinite, describing it as non-percipient & non-non-percipient.

original: ‘Nevantavā nānantavā attā hoti arogo paraṁ maraṇā nevasaññīnāsaññī’ti naṁ paññapenti.
analyzed: nevantavā na anantavā attā hoti arogo param maraṇā nevasaññī nāsaññī iti nam paññapenti
translated: ‘After death, the self is neither percipient nor non-percipient and is healthy.’

original: Imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā nevasaññīnāsaññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṁ nevasaññīnāsaññiṁ attānaṁ paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi.
analyzed: imehi kho te bhikkhave samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ uddhamāghātanikāḥ nevasaññīnāsaññīvādāḥ uddhamāghātanam nevasaññīnāsaññim attānam paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi
translated: These are the eight ways.

original: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā uddhamāghātanikā nevasaññīnāsaññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṁ nevasaññīnāsaññiṁ attānaṁ paññapenti, sabbe te imeheva aṭṭhahi vatthūhi …🔽pe…
analyzed: ye hi keci bhikkhave samaṇāḥ vā brāhmaṇāḥ vā uddhamāghātanikāḥ nevasaññīnāsaññī vādāḥ uddhamāghātanam nevasaññīnāsaññim attānam paññapenti sabbe te imehi eva aṭṭhahi vatthūhi  pe
translated: “Whatever ascetics and brahmins proclaim a self that is formless and infinite after death, all of them do so on these eight grounds. …

original: yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṁ vaṇṇaṁ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṁ.
analyzed: ye hi tathāgatassa yathābhuccam vaṇṇam sammā vadamānāḥ vadeyyu
translated: … they would describe the Tathāgata in accordance with reality.

original: 3.2.4. Ucchedavāda
analyzed: uccheda vāda
translated: … Annihilationism

original: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā ucchedavādā sato sattassa ucchedaṁ vināsaṁ vibhavaṁ paññapenti sattahi vatthūhi.

translated: “There are some ascetics and brahmins who are annihilationists, who proclaim the annihilation, destruction, and extermination of an existing being. They do so on eight grounds.

original: Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha ucchedavādā sato sattassa ucchedaṁ vināsaṁ vibhavaṁ paññapenti sattahi vatthūhi?
analyzed: te ca bhonto samaṇa brāhmaṇā kim āgamma kim ārabbha uccheda vādā sataḥ sattassa ucchedam vināsam vibhavam paññapenti sattahi vatthūhi
translated: And on the basis of what are they doing so?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā evaṁvādī hoti evaṁdiṭṭhi:
analyzed: idha bhikkhave ekaccaḥ samaṇaḥ vā brāhmaṇaḥ vā eva vādī hoti eva diṭṭhi
translated: “There is the case where a certain contemplative or brahmāin comes to hold the view, comes to hold the conviction, ‘As far as this self, obtained by personal experience, is percipient of form, is percipient of feeling, is percipient of perception, is percipient of fabrications, is percipient of consciousness, it is percipient of what is percipient of that.🔽When the body breaks up, with the ending of life, this self is percipient of form, percipient of feeling, percipient of perception, percipient of fabrications, percipient of consciousness, percipient of what is percipient of that.

original: ‘yato kho, bho, ayaṁ attā rūpī cātumahābhūtiko mātāpettikasambhavo kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraṁ maraṇā, ettāvatā kho, bho, ayaṁ attā sammā samucchinno hotī’ti.
analyzed: yatas kho bho ayam attā rūpī cātumahābhūtikaḥ mātā pettika sambhavo kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati vinassati na hoti param maraṇā ettāvatā kho bho ayam attā sammā samucchinnaḥ hoti iti
translated: This self is annihilated, destroyed, & does not exist after death.’

original: Ittheke sato sattassa ucchedaṁ vināsaṁ vibhavaṁ paññapenti.🔽Tamañño evamāha:
analyzed: itthā ike sataḥ sattassa ucchedam vināsam vibhavam paññapenti  evam āha
translated: This is the first case in which they declare the annihilation, destruction, & non-existence of a self that is percipient.🔽“Another brahmāin or contemplative comes to hold the view, comes to hold the conviction,

analyzed: atthi kho bho esaḥ attā yam tvam vadesi na iso natthi iti vadāmi

original: Atthi kho, bho, añño attā dibbo rūpī kāmāvacaro kabaḷīkārāhārabhakkho.
analyzed: atthi kho bho aññaḥ attā dibbaḥ rūpī kāma avacaraḥ kabaḷīkāra āhāra bhakkho
translated: There is another self, divine, material,633 blissful,634 and free of disease, which is permanent, everlasting, eternal, and imperishable.

original: Taṁ tvaṁ na jānāsi na passasi.
analyzed: tam tvam na jānāsi na passasi
translated: You don’t know it or see it,

analyzed: tam aham jānāmi passāmi  saḥ kho bho attā yatas kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati vinassati na hoti param maraṇā ettāvatā kho bho ayam attā sammā samucchinnaḥ hoti iti
translated: I know and see it.🔽That self, when the body breaks up, perishes and is destroyed and does not exist after death. It is in this way that some proclaim a doctrine of annihilation,

original: Ittheke sato sattassa ucchedaṁ vināsaṁ vibhavaṁ paññapenti.

analyzed: tam tvam na jānāsi na passasi
translated: You do not know it, you do not see it.

translated: I know it, I see it.🔽That self, when the body breaks up, perishes and is destroyed and does not exist after death. It is in this way that some proclaim a doctrine of annihilation,

original: Atthi kho, bho, añño attā sabbaso rūpasaññānaṁ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṁ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṁ amanasikārā “ananto ākāso”ti ākāsānañcāyatanūpago.

translated: There is, friend, another self that has completely transcended material form, has destroyed sensory reaction, and is not aware of any multiplicity. It is attained in the sphere of infinite space.

original: Taṁ tvaṁ na jānāsi na passasi.
analyzed: tam tvam na jānāsi na passasi

original: Atthi kho, bho, añño attā sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ samatikkamma “santametaṁ paṇītametan”ti nevasaññānāsaññāyatanūpago.

original: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā ucchedavādā sato sattassa ucchedaṁ vināsaṁ vibhavaṁ paññapenti, sabbe te imeheva sattahi vatthūhi …🔽pe…
analyzed: ye hi keci bhikkhave samaṇāḥ vā brāhmaṇāḥ vā uccheda vādāḥ sataḥ sattassa ucchedam vināsam vibhavam paññapenti sabbe te imehi iva sattahi vatthūhi  pe
translated: “Any ascetics and brahmins who proclaim the annihilation, destruction, and extermination of an existing being do so in these seven ways. …🔽… they would speak in accordance with what has been said by me, not contrary to what has been said by me, and would explain in accordance with the Dhamma.

original: yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṁ vaṇṇaṁ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṁ.🔽3.2.5. Diṭṭhadhammanibbānavāda

original: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādā sato sattassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṁ paññapenti pañcahi vatthūhi.

translated: “Monks, there are some ascetics and brahmins who proclaim the annihilation, destruction, and extermination of an existing being right here and now. They do so in five ways.

original: Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādā sato sattassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṁ paññapenti pañcahi vatthūhi?
analyzed: te ca bhonto samaṇa brāhmaṇā kim āgamma kim ārabbha diṭṭhadhamma nibbāna vādā sataḥ sattassa parama diṭṭhadhamma nibbānam paññapenti pañcahi vatthūhi
translated: And on what basis do they do so?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā evaṁvādī hoti evaṁdiṭṭhi:
analyzed: idha bhikkhave ekaccaḥ samaṇaḥ vā brāhmaṇaḥ vā eva vādī hoti eva diṭṭhi
translated: “Here, bhikkhus, some recluse or brahmin is a speculator about the past, holding such a view as this:🔽‘When one gives a gift to a worthy recipient, then by that means alone one becomes uplifted and happy.

original: ‘yato kho, bho, ayaṁ attā pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricāreti, ettāvatā kho, bho, ayaṁ attā paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṁ patto hotī’ti.🔽Ittheke sato sattassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṁ paññapenti.

translated: In this way one becomes uplifted and happy in the present world and in the future world.’🔽This is the first way in which some recluses and brahmins proclaim a doctrine of conscious post-mortem existence.

original: Tamañño evamāha:
analyzed: evam āha
translated: Another says:

original: ‘atthi kho, bho, eso attā, yaṁ tvaṁ vadesi, neso natthīti vadāmi;
analyzed: atthi kho bho esaḥ attā yam tvam vadesi na iso natthi iti vadāmi
translated: ‘There is, indeed, such a self as you affirm, I do not say that there is not;

original: no ca kho, bho, ayaṁ attā ettāvatā paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṁ patto hoti.
analyzed: no ca kho bho ayam attā ettāvatā parama diṭṭhadhamma nibbānam pattaḥ hoti
translated: but that self does not become uplifted and happy in the present world and in the future world by that means alone.

original: Taṁ kissa hetu?🔽Kāmā hi, bho, aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammā, tesaṁ vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā uppajjanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā.
analyzed: tam kim sa hetu  kāmāḥ hi bho aniccāḥ dukkhāḥ vipariṇāma dhammāḥ tesam vipariṇāma aññathābhāvāḥ uppajjanti soka parideva dukkha domanassa upāyāsāḥ
translated: And why is that?🔽Because sensual pleasures are impermanent, suffering, and subject to change, and it is by their change and transformation that sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair arise in one who craves for them.

original: Yato kho, bho, ayaṁ attā vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ
analyzed: yatas kho bho ayam attā vivicca iva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi sa vitakkam sa vicāra
translated: When one turns away from sensual pleasures, turns away from unwholesome states, and enters upon and abides in the first jhana, which is accompanied by applied and sustained thought, with rapture and pleasure born of seclusion,

original: vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati, ettāvatā kho, bho, ayaṁ
analyzed: viveka jam pīti sukham paṭhamam jhānam upasampajja viharati ettāvatā kho bho
translated: He enters and dwells in the first jhāna, which consists of rapture and pleasure born of seclusion, accompanied by thought and examination. It is in this way, friend,

original: attā paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṁ patto hotī’ti.
analyzed: attā parama diṭṭhadhamma nibbānam pattaḥ hoti iti
translated: that one attains the supreme state of sublime peace in this very life.’

original: Ittheke sato sattassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṁ paññapenti.
analyzed: itthā ike sataḥ sattassa parama diṭṭhadhamma nibbānam paññapenti
translated: This is how some proclaim a doctrine of conscious post-mortem survival.

original: Tamañño evamāha:
analyzed: evam āha
translated: Another says:

original: ‘atthi kho, bho, eso attā, yaṁ tvaṁ vadesi, neso natthīti vadāmi;
analyzed: atthi kho bho esaḥ attā yam tvam vadesi na iso natthi iti vadāmi
translated: ‘There is, friend, such a self as you hold to be the self, I do not deny it.

original: no ca kho, bho, ayaṁ attā ettāvatā paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṁ patto hoti.
analyzed: no ca kho bho ayam attā ettāvatā parama diṭṭhadhamma nibbānam pattaḥ hoti
translated: But this self does not attain the supreme state of sublime peace in this very life.

original: Taṁ kissa hetu?🔽Yadeva tattha vitakkitaṁ vicāritaṁ, etenetaṁ oḷārikaṁ akkhāyati.
analyzed: tam kim sa hetu  yat eva tattha vitakkitam vicāritaḥ etena itam oḷārikam akkhāyati
translated: Why is that?

original: Yato kho, bho, ayaṁ attā vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā ajjhattaṁ sampasādanaṁ cetaso
analyzed: yatas kho bho ayam attā vitakka vicārānam vūpasamāḥ ajjhattam sampasādanam cetasaḥ
translated: Because there is thought and examination here, and that is why this is declared to be gross.

original: ekodibhāvaṁ avitakkaṁ avicāraṁ samādhijaṁ pītisukhaṁ dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati,
analyzed: eka ādi bhāvam a vitakkam a vicāram samādhi jam pīti sukham dutiyam jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: But when this self, with the subsiding of thought and examination, enters and dwells in the second jhāna, which is … born of concentration, and is accompanied by rapture and pleasure,

original: ettāvatā kho, bho, ayaṁ attā paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṁ patto hotī’ti.
analyzed: ettāvatā kho bho ayam attā parama diṭṭhadhamma nibbānam pattaḥ hoti iti
translated: it is in this way that one attains the supreme state of sublime peace in this very life.’

original: Ittheke sato sattassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṁ paññapenti.
analyzed: itthā ike sataḥ sattassa parama diṭṭhadhamma nibbānam paññapenti
translated: This is how some proclaim a presently existing self that is formless and infinite.

original: Tamañño evamāha:
analyzed: evam āha
translated: Another says:

original: ‘atthi kho, bho, eso attā, yaṁ tvaṁ vadesi, neso natthīti vadāmi;
analyzed: atthi kho bho esaḥ attā yam tvam vadesi na iso natthi iti vadāmi
translated: ‘There is, my friend, such a self as you affirm, I do not say there is not.

original: no ca kho, bho, ayaṁ attā ettāvatā paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṁ patto hoti.
analyzed: no ca kho bho ayam attā ettāvatā parama diṭṭhadhamma nibbānam pattaḥ hoti
translated: But this self has not yet attained the highest type of destruction.

original: Taṁ kissa hetu?
analyzed: tam kim sa hetu
translated: Why is that?

original: Yadeva tattha pītigataṁ cetaso uppilāvitattaṁ, etenetaṁ oḷārikaṁ akkhāyati.🔽Yato kho, bho, ayaṁ attā pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati, sato ca sampajāno,
analyzed: yat eva tattha pīti gatam cetasaḥ uppilāvitatte etena itam oḷārikam akkhāyati  yatas kho bho ayam attā pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati sataḥ ca sampajānaḥ
translated: Because there is still a certain coarseness there in the mind.

original: sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṁvedeti, yaṁ taṁ ariyā ācikkhanti “upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī”ti,
analyzed: sukham ca kāyena paṭisavedeti yam tam ariyāḥ ācikkhanti upekkhakaḥ satimā sukha vihārī iti
translated: When, with the fading away of rapture, a bhikkhu abides in equanimity, and mindfully and fully aware, still feeling pleasure with the body,

original: tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati, ettāvatā kho, bho, ayaṁ attā paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṁ patto hotī’ti.
analyzed: tatiyam jhānam upasampajja viharati ettāvatā kho bho ayam attā parama diṭṭhadhamma nibbānam pattaḥ hoti iti
translated: he enters and dwells in the third jhana, on that occasion this self has attained the highest type of destruction.’

original: Ittheke sato sattassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṁ paññapenti.
analyzed: itthā ike sataḥ sattassa parama diṭṭhadhamma nibbānam paññapenti
translated: This is how some proclaim a presently existing self that is formless and infinite.

original: Tamañño evamāha:
analyzed: evam āha
translated: Another says:

original: ‘atthi kho, bho, eso attā, yaṁ tvaṁ vadesi, neso natthīti vadāmi;
analyzed: atthi kho bho esaḥ attā yam tvam vadesi na iso natthi iti vadāmi
translated: ‘There is, good sir, such a self as you refer to, I do not say there is not;🔽but this self does not, by the complete surmounting of perceptions of form,🔽by the disappearance of perceptions of sensory reaction, by non-attention to perceptions of diversity,🔽aware of ‘there is nothing’, enter and remain in the fourth jhāna, which is neither painful nor pleasant and includes the purification of mindfulness by equanimity.

original: no ca kho, bho, ayaṁ attā ettāvatā paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṁ patto hoti.
analyzed: no ca kho bho ayam attā ettāvatā parama diṭṭhadhamma nibbānam pattaḥ hoti
translated: This self, good sir, has not attained complete nibbāna in the here and now.

original: Taṁ kissa hetu?
analyzed: tam kim sa hetu
translated: And why is that?

original: Yadeva tattha sukhamiti cetaso ābhogo, etenetaṁ oḷārikaṁ akkhāyati.
analyzed: yat eva tattha sukham iti cetasaḥ ābhogaḥ etena itam oḷārikam akkhāyati
translated: Because of the mental fixation on ‘there is happiness’ here, this is said to be gross.

original: Yato kho, bho, ayaṁ attā sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ
analyzed: yatas kho bho ayam attā sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbā iva somanassa domanassāna
translated: But when this self, by the abandoning of pleasure and pain, by the disappearance of former gladness and sadness,

analyzed: atthaṅgamā adukkham asukham upekkhā sati pārisuddhim catuttham jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: enters and remains in the fourth jhāna, which is neither painful nor pleasant and includes the purification of mindfulness by equanimity,

original: ettāvatā kho, bho, ayaṁ attā paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṁ patto hotī’ti.🔽Ittheke sato sattassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṁ paññapenti.
analyzed: ettāvatā kho bho ayam attā parama diṭṭhadhamma nibbānam pattaḥ hoti iti  itthā ike sataḥ sattassa parama diṭṭhadhamma nibbānam paññapenti
translated: this self, good sir, has attained complete nibbāna in the here and now.’🔽This is how some ascetics and brahmins proclaim a here and now nibbāna for an existent being based on the five bases.

original: Imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādā sato sattassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṁ paññapenti pañcahi vatthūhi.
analyzed: imehi kho te bhikkhave samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ diṭṭhadhamma nibbāna vādāḥ sataḥ sattassa parama diṭṭhadhamma nibbānam paññapenti pañcahi vatthūhi
translated: These, monks, are the ascetics and brahmins who proclaim a here and now nibbāna for an existent being based on five bases.

original: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādā sato sattassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṁ paññapenti, sabbe te imeheva pañcahi vatthūhi …🔽pe…
analyzed: ye hi keci bhikkhave samaṇāḥ vā brāhmaṇāḥ vā diṭṭhadhamma nibbāna vādāḥ sataḥ sattassa parama diṭṭhadhamma nibbānam paññapenti sabbe te imehi eva pañcahi vatthūhi  pe
translated: “Any ascetics or brahmins who proclaim the annihilation, destruction, and extermination of an existent being at death, all of them do so on these five grounds. …🔽… the Tathāgata …

original: yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṁ vaṇṇaṁ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṁ.
analyzed: ye hi tathāgatassa yathābhuccam vaṇṇam sammā vadamānāḥ vadeyyu
translated: would rightly speak praise of him.

original: Imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā aparantakappikā aparantānudiṭṭhino aparantaṁ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti catucattārīsāya vatthūhi.🔽Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā aparantakappikā aparantānudiṭṭhino aparantaṁ
analyzed: imehi kho te bhikkhave samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ aparanta kappikāḥ aparanta anudiṭṭhinaḥ aparantam ārabbha aneka vihitāni adhimutti padāni abhivadanti catucattārīsāya vatthūhi  ye hi keci bhikkhave samaṇāḥ vā brāhmaṇāḥ vā aparanta kappikāḥ aparanta anudiṭṭhinaḥ aparanta
translated: “These are the twenty-four grounds on which those ascetics and brahmins who are speculators about the future, having fixed ideas about the future, put forward various speculative theories concerning the future.

original: ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti, sabbe te imeheva catucattārīsāya vatthūhi …🔽pe…
analyzed: ārabbha aneka vihitāni adhimutti padāni abhivadanti sabbe te imehi iva catucattārīsāya vatthūhi  pe
translated: “Any ascetics and brahmins who are speculators about the future, having fixed ideas about the future, and who put forward various speculative theories concerning the future, all of them do so on these twenty-four grounds. …🔽… the Tathāgata …

original: yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṁ vaṇṇaṁ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṁ.
analyzed: ye hi tathāgatassa yathābhuccam vaṇṇam sammā vadamānāḥ vadeyyu
translated: would rightly speak praise of him.

original: Imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā pubbantakappikā ca aparantakappikā ca pubbantāparantakappikā🔽ca pubbantāparantānudiṭṭhino pubbantāparantaṁ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni
analyzed: imehi kho te bhikkhave samaṇa brāhmaṇā pubbanta kappikā ca aparanta kappikā ca pubbanta aparanta kappikā  ca pubbanta aparanta anudiṭṭhinaḥ pubbanta aparantam ārabbha aneka vihitāni adhimutti padāni
translated: These are the ascetics and brahmins who are speculators about the past, speculators about the future, or speculators about the past and the future in various ways.🔽They are bound by the fetter of speculation, cut off by the cycle of birth and death, and are unable to escape the world’s pilgrimage.

original: abhivadanti dvāsaṭṭhiyā vatthūhi.
analyzed: abhivadanti dvāsaṭṭhiyā vatthūhi
translated: These are the sixty-two cases of views.

original: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā pubbantakappikā vā aparantakappikā vā
analyzed: ye hi keci bhikkhave samaṇāḥ vā brāhmaṇāḥ vā pubbantakappikāḥ vā aparantakappikāḥ vā
translated: “There are some ascetics and brahmins, monks, who are speculators about the past, who are speculators about the future, who are speculators about the past and the future,

original: pubbantāparantakappikā vā pubbantāparantānudiṭṭhino pubbantāparantaṁ ārabbha anekavihitāni
analyzed: pubbanta aparanta kappikāḥ vā pubbanta aparanta anudiṭṭhinaḥ pubbanta aparantam ārabbha aneka vihitāni
translated: who are proclaimers of a doctrine of the past and the future, who are speculators about the fruits of the future, who are speculators about chance and signs, who are speculators about the elements, who are speculators about making a living, who are speculators about what is not the case, who are speculators about what is.

original: adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti, sabbe te imeheva dvāsaṭṭhiyā vatthūhi, etesaṁ vā aññatarena;
analyzed: adhimutti padāni abhivadanti sabbe te imehi iva dvāsaṭṭhiyāḥ vatthūhi etesam vā aññatarena
translated: They proclaim sixty-two cases of views based on these twenty principles.

original: natthi ito bahiddhā.
analyzed: na atthi itas bahiddhā
translated: There is no other way.

original: Tayidaṁ, bhikkhave, tathāgato pajānāti:
analyzed: tayida bhikkhave tathāgataḥ pajānāti
translated: The Tathagata understands this:

original: ‘ime diṭṭhiṭṭhānā evaṅgahitā evaṁparāmaṭṭhā evaṅgatikā bhavanti evaṁabhisamparāyā’ti.
analyzed: ime diṭṭhi ṭṭhānāḥ evaṅgahitāḥ eva parāmaṭṭhāḥ evaṅgatikāḥ bhavanti eva abhisamparāyāti
translated: ‘If these views are taken thus, they lead to such a destination in another world; if these views are taken thus, they lead to such a destination in another world.’

original: Tañca tathāgato pajānāti, tato ca uttaritaraṁ pajānāti, tañca pajānanaṁ na parāmasati, aparāmasato cassa paccattaññeva nibbuti viditā.
analyzed: tat ca tathāgataḥ pajānāti tatas ca uttaritaram pajānāti tat ca pajānanam na parāmasati a parāmasataḥ ca ssa paccattaññā eva nibbuti viditā
translated: The Tathagata understands this, and he understands something higher than this understanding, and that understanding does not obsess him, since he is not bound to it, and being unboun­d he has understood liberation.

original: Vedanānaṁ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṁ viditvā anupādāvimutto, bhikkhave, tathāgato.
analyzed: vedanānam samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtam viditvā an upādā vimuttaḥ bhikkhave tathāgataḥ
translated: The Tathagata is liberated through non-clinging by having given up sen­sation’s origination, passing away, gratification, danger, and escape.

original: Ime kho te, bhikkhave, dhammā gambhīrā duddasā duranubodhā santā paṇītā atakkāvacarā🔽nipuṇā paṇḍitavedanīyā, ye tathāgato sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti, yehi tathāgatassa🔽yathābhuccaṁ vaṇṇaṁ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṁ.
analyzed: ime kho te bhikkhave dhammā gambhīrāḥ duddasāḥ duranubodhā santā paṇītāḥ a takka avacarā  nipuṇā paṇḍita vedanīyāḥ ye tathāgataḥ sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti yehi tathāgatassa  yathābhuccam vaṇṇam sammā vadamānāḥ vadeyyu
translated: These things, bhikkhus, are deep, hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful, sublime, beyond the sphere of reasoning, recondite, comprehensible only to the wise.

original: 4. Attālokapaññattivatthu🔽4.1. Paritassitavipphanditavāra🔽Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā sassataṁ attānañca lokañca paññapenti
analyzed: 🔽paritassita vipphandita vāra 🔽tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇā sassata vādā sassatam attānam ca lokañca paññapenti
translated: They are not to be grasped by mere rea­soning thus: ‘It might be so, it might not be so.’ But the Tathagata, bhikkhus, having realised them by his own super-knowledge, proclaims them, reveals them, makes them known, esta­blishes them, exposes them, and explains them.

original: catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṁ bhavataṁ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṁ ajānataṁ apassataṁ vedayitaṁ🔽taṇhāgatānaṁ paritassitavipphanditameva.🔽Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṁ sassataṁ

translated: “Whatever ascetics and brahmins proclaim a doctrine of eternalism in four aspects, all of them do so on these four grounds or on a certain one of them.🔽Yet those venerable contemplatives and brahmins, not knowing and not seeing the right end of views,

original: ekaccaṁ asassataṁ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṁ bhavataṁ🔽samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṁ ajānataṁ apassataṁ vedayitaṁ taṇhāgatānaṁ paritassitavipphanditameva.
analyzed: ekaccam a sassatam attānam ca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi tat api tesam bhavata  samaṇa brāhmaṇānam a jānatam a passatam vedayitam taṇhā gatānam paritassita vipphanditam eva
translated: “Whatever ascetics and brahmins proclaim a doctrine of partial-eternalism and partial-noneternalism in four aspects, all of them do so on these four grounds or on a certain one of them.

original: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā antānantikā antānantaṁ lokassa paññapenti
analyzed: tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ anta anantikāḥ anta anantam lokassa paññapenti
translated: Yet those venerable contemplatives and brahmins, not knowing and not seeing the right end of views,

original: catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṁ bhavataṁ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṁ ajānataṁ apassataṁ vedayitaṁ🔽taṇhāgatānaṁ paritassitavipphanditameva.
analyzed: catūhi vatthūhi tat api tesam bhavatam samaṇa brāhmaṇānam a jānatam a passatam vedayita  taṇhā gatānam paritassita vipphanditam eva
translated: “Whatever ascetics and brahmins proclaim a doctrine of finitude or infinitude of the world in four aspects, all of them do so on these four grounds or on a certain one of them.

original: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā amarāvikkhepikā tattha tattha pañhaṁ puṭṭhā
analyzed: tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ tattha tattha pañham puṭṭhāḥ
translated: Yet those venerable contemplatives and brahmins, not knowing and not seeing the right end of views,🔽“Whatever ascetics and brahmins are speculators about the past, the future, or both, and proclaim a doctrine of speculation in four aspects, all of them do so on these four grounds or on a certain one of them.

original: samānā vācāvikkhepaṁ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṁ catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṁ bhavataṁ🔽samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṁ ajānataṁ apassataṁ vedayitaṁ taṇhāgatānaṁ paritassitavipphanditameva.🔽Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā adhiccasamuppannikā adhiccasamuppannaṁ attānañca
analyzed: samānāḥ vācā vikkhepam āpajjanti amarā vikkhepam catūhi vatthūhi tat api tesam bhavata  samaṇa brāhmaṇānam a jānatam a passatam vedayitam taṇhā gatānam paritassita vipphanditam eva  tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ adhiccasamuppannikāḥ adhiccasamuppannam attānam ca
translated: “Therein, monks, as for those contemplatives & brahmans who are chance-originationists, proclaiming the self and the cosmos to be chance-originated, on four grounds:

analyzed: lokañca paññapenti dvīhi vatthūhi tat api tesam bhavatam samaṇa brāhmaṇānam ajānata  a passatam vedayitam taṇhāgatānam paritassita vipphanditam eva  tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇā pubbanta kappikā pubbanta anudiṭṭhinaḥ pubbanta  ārabbha aneka vihitāni adhimutti padāni abhivadanti aṭṭhārasahi vatthūhi tat api
translated: This is just worry and vacillation on the part of those venerable contemplatives & brahmans who don’t know and don’t see, who are possessed, appropriated, and their minds consumed with craving for continued existence, so that they declare the self and the cosmos to be chance-originated on four grounds.🔽“Therein, monks, as for those contemplatives & brahmans who are speculators about the past, holding settled views about the past, and who on four grounds proclaim various speculative views about the past, on eighteen grounds:

analyzed: bhavatam samaṇa brāhmaṇānam a jānatam a passatam vedayitam taṇhāgatānam paritassita vipphanditam eva
translated: This is just worry and vacillation on the part of those venerable contemplatives & brahmans who don’t know and don’t see, who are possessed, appropriated, and their minds consumed with craving for continued existence, so that they proclaim various speculative views about the past on eighteen grounds.

original: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā saññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṁ
analyzed: tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ uddhamāghātanikā saññīvādāḥ uddhamāghātana
translated: “Now, bhikkhus, those ascetics and brahmins who are of the view that the self after death is percipient and possesses form,🔽

translated: “Therein, bhikkhus, in regard to those ascetics and brahmins who are of the view that the self is percipient after death and who on sixteen grounds proclaim a self that is percipient after death, this belief of theirs has simply arisen from unwise attention to what is actually the case.

original: asaññiṁ attānaṁ paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṁ bhavataṁ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṁ🔽ajānataṁ apassataṁ vedayitaṁ taṇhāgatānaṁ paritassitavipphanditameva.🔽Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā nevasaññīnāsaññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṁ
analyzed: asaññim attānam paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi tat api tesam bhavatam samaṇa brāhmaṇāna  a jānatam a passatam vedayitam taṇhā gatānam paritassita vipphanditam eva  tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ uddham āghātanikāḥ nevasaññī nāsaññī vādāḥ uddham āghātana
translated: “Therein, bhikkhus, in regard to those ascetics and brahmins who are of the view that the self is non-percipient after death and who on eight grounds proclaim a self that is non-percipient after death, this belief of theirs has simply arisen from unwise attention to what is actually the case.

original: nevasaññīnāsaññiṁ attānaṁ paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṁ bhavataṁ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṁ
analyzed: nevasaññī na asaññim attānam paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi tat api tesam bhavatam samaṇa brāhmaṇānam
translated: “Therein, bhikkhus, in regard to those ascetics and brahmins who are of the view that the self is neither percipient nor non-percipient after death and who on eight grounds proclaim a self that is neither percipient nor non-percipient after death, this belief of theirs has simply arisen from unwise attention to what is actually the case.🔽“Therein, bhikkhus, in regard to those ascetics and brahmins who are of the view that the self is percipient after death and who on sixteen grounds proclaim a self that is percipient after death, this belief of theirs has simply arisen from unwise attention to what is actually the case.

original: ajānataṁ apassataṁ vedayitaṁ taṇhāgatānaṁ paritassitavipphanditameva.🔽Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā ucchedavādā sato sattassa ucchedaṁ vināsaṁ
analyzed: a jānatam a passatam vedayitam taṇhā gatānam paritassita vipphanditam eva  tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ uccheda vādāḥ sataḥ sattassa ucchedam
translated: for those who do not know or see, but are prey to craving and subject to fear and trembling.

original: vibhavaṁ paññapenti sattahi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṁ bhavataṁ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṁ ajānataṁ🔽apassataṁ vedayitaṁ taṇhāgatānaṁ paritassitavipphanditameva.🔽Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādā sato sattassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṁ
analyzed: vibhavam paññapenti sattahi vatthūhi tat api tesam bhavatam samaṇa brāhmaṇānam ajānata  a passatam vedayitam taṇhāgatānam paritassita vipphanditam eva  tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ diṭṭhadhamma nibbāna vādāḥ sataḥ sattassa parama diṭṭhadhamma nibbāna
translated: “Therein, bhikkhus, those ascetics and brahmins who are annihilationists, who proclaim the annihilation, destruction, and extermination of an existent being, on seven grounds: this too is their trembling, their fear, their timidity.

original: paññapenti pañcahi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṁ bhavataṁ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṁ ajānataṁ apassataṁ🔽vedayitaṁ taṇhāgatānaṁ paritassitavipphanditameva.
analyzed: paññapenti pañcahi vatthūhi tat api tesam bhavatam samaṇa brāhmaṇānam a jānatam apassata  vedayitam taṇhā gatānam paritassita vipphanditam eva
translated: “Therein, bhikkhus, those ascetics and brahmins who are of the doctrine of a real world, who proclaim a real world, on five grounds: this too is their trembling, their fear, their timidity.

original: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā aparantakappikā aparantānudiṭṭhino aparantaṁ
analyzed: tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ aparanta kappikāḥ aparanta anudiṭṭhinaḥ aparanta
translated: “Therein, bhikkhus, those ascetics and brahmins who are speculators about the future, who proclaim a doctrine of the future, on four grounds: this too is their trembling, their fear, their timidity.

original: ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti catucattārīsāya vatthūhi, tadapi
analyzed: ārabbha aneka vihitāni adhimutti padāni abhivadanti catucattārīsāya vatthūhi tat api
translated: and the many speculative views that arise in dependence on the present life, all these views are based on the six elements.

original: tesaṁ bhavataṁ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṁ ajānataṁ apassataṁ vedayitaṁ taṇhāgatānaṁ paritassitavipphanditameva.🔽Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā pubbantakappikā ca aparantakappikā ca pubbantāparantakappikā🔽ca pubbantāparantānudiṭṭhino pubbantāparantaṁ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni
analyzed: tesam bhavatam samaṇa brāhmaṇānam a jānatam a passatam vedayitam taṇhā gatānam paritassita vipphanditam eva  tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇā pubbantakappikā ca aparantakappikā ca pubbanta aparantakappikā  ca pubbanta aparanta anudiṭṭhinaḥ pubbanta aparantam ārabbha aneka vihitāni adhimutti padāni
translated: This is the source, the origin, the birth, the arising, the production, the origination of those various speculative views, that is, the six elements.🔽“Therein, bhikkhus, those ascetics and brahmins who are speculators about the past and hold settled views about the past, and who on forty-four grounds assert various conceptual theorems referring to the past, all of them do so on the basis of that same sixfold element base.

original: abhivadanti dvāsaṭṭhiyā vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṁ bhavataṁ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṁ ajānataṁ🔽apassataṁ vedayitaṁ taṇhāgatānaṁ paritassitavipphanditameva.
analyzed: abhivadanti tat api tesam bhavatam samaṇa brāhmaṇānam ajānata  a passatam vedayitam taṇhāgatānam paritassita vipphanditam eva
translated: This is the source, the origin, the birth, the arising, the production, the origination of those various speculative views, that is, the six elements.

original: 4.2. Phassapaccayāvāra
analyzed: phassa paccaya āvāra
translated: .. Dependent on contact

original: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā sassataṁ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi phassapaccayā.
analyzed: tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇā sassata vādā sassatam attānam ca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi tat api phassa paccayā
translated: “Therein, bhikkhus, those ascetics and brahmins who are eternalists and proclaim the eternity of the self and the world on four grounds, that is also dependent on contact.

original: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṁ sassataṁ ekaccaṁ asassataṁ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi phassapaccayā.
analyzed: tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ ekacca sassatikāḥ ekacca asassatikāḥ ekaccam sassatam ekaccam asassatam attānam ca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi tat api phassa paccayā
translated: “The self and the world are partly eternal and partly not eternal: this is the fourth way. These four ways are dependent on the four foundations.🔽“The self and the world are finite and infinite: this is the fifth way. These five ways are dependent on the four foundations.

original: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā antānantikā antānantaṁ lokassa paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi phassapaccayā.
analyzed: tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ anta anantikāḥ anta anantam lokassa paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi tat api phassa paccayā
translated: “The self and the world are not finite and not infinite: this is the sixth way. These six ways are dependent on the four foundations.🔽“The self and the world are both eternal and not eternal: this is the seventh way. These seven ways are dependent on the four foundations.

original: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā amarāvikkhepikā tattha tattha pañhaṁ puṭṭhā samānā vācāvikkhepaṁ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṁ catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi phassapaccayā.
analyzed: tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ amara avikkhepikā tattha tattha pañham puṭṭhā samānā vācā vikkhepam āpajjanti amara avikkhepam catūhi vatthūhi tat api phassa paccayā
translated: “The self and the world are neither eternal nor not eternal: this is the eighth way. These eight ways are dependent on the four foundations.🔽“The self and the world are made by oneself: this is the ninth way. These nine ways are dependent on the four foundations.

original: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā adhiccasamuppannikā adhiccasamuppannaṁ attānañca lokañca paññapenti dvīhi vatthūhi, tadapi phassapaccayā.
analyzed: tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ adhiccasamuppannikāḥ adhiccasamuppannam attānam ca lokañca paññapenti dvīhi vatthūhi tat api phassa paccayā
translated: “The self and the world are made by another: this is the tenth way. These ten ways are dependent on the four foundations.

original: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā pubbantakappikā pubbantānudiṭṭhino pubbantaṁ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti aṭṭhārasahi vatthūhi, tadapi phassapaccayā.
analyzed: tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇā pubbanta kappikā pubbanta anudiṭṭhino pubbantam ārabbha aneka vihitāni adhimutti padāni abhivadanti aṭṭhārasahi vatthūhi tat api phassa paccayā
translated: “The views of those ascetics and brahmins who are speculators about the past, and who on fourteen grounds assert various speculative theories about the past, are rooted in the six bases of contact.🔽“The views of those ascetics and brahmins who are speculators about the future, and who on sixteen grounds assert various speculative theories about the future, are rooted in the six bases of contact.🔽“The views of those ascetics and brahmins who are speculators about the future, and who on eight grounds assert various speculative theories about the future, are rooted in the six bases of contact.

original: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā saññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṁ saññiṁ attānaṁ paññapenti soḷasahi vatthūhi, tadapi phassapaccayā.🔽Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā asaññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṁ asaññiṁ attānaṁ paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi, tadapi phassapaccayā.🔽Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā nevasaññīnāsaññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṁ nevasaññīnāsaññiṁ attānaṁ paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi, tadapi phassapaccayā.
analyzed: tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ uddhamāghātanikā saññīvādāḥ uddhamāghātanam saññim attānam paññapenti soḷasahi vatthūhi tat api phassa paccayā 🔽tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ uddhamāghātanikāḥ asaññī vādāḥ uddhamāghātanam asaññim attānam paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi tat api phassa paccayā 🔽tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ uddhamāghātanikāḥ nevasaññīnāsaññīvādāḥ uddhamāghātanam nevasaññīnāsaññim attānam paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi tat api phassa paccayā
translated: “The views of those ascetics and brahmins who are speculators about the future, and who on eight grounds assert various speculative theories about the future, are rooted in the six bases of contact.

original: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā ucchedavādā sato sattassa ucchedaṁ vināsaṁ vibhavaṁ paññapenti sattahi vatthūhi, tadapi phassapaccayā.🔽Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādā sato sattassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṁ paññapenti pañcahi vatthūhi, tadapi phassapaccayā.
analyzed: tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ uccheda vādāḥ sataḥ sattassa ucchedam vināsam vibhavam paññapenti sattahi vatthūhi tat api phassa paccayā  tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ diṭṭhadhamma nibbāna vādāḥ sataḥ sattassa parama diṭṭhadhamma nibbānam paññapenti pañcahi vatthūhi tat api phassa paccayā
translated: “Therein, bhikkhus, in regard to those recluses and brahmins who are annihilationists and who on seven grounds proclaim the annihilation, destruction, and extermination of an existent being, that is dependent on contact.🔽“Therein, bhikkhus, in regard to those recluses and brahmins who are of the doctrine of a purified self and who on five grounds proclaim the purification of the self, that is dependent on contact.

original: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā aparantakappikā aparantānudiṭṭhino aparantaṁ🔽ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti catucattārīsāya vatthūhi, tadapi phassapaccayā.
analyzed: tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ aparanta kappikāḥ aparanta anudiṭṭhinaḥ aparanta  ārabbha aneka vihitāni adhimutti padāni abhivadanti catucattārīsāya vatthūhi tat api phassa paccayā
translated: “Therein, bhikkhus, in regard to those recluses and brahmins who are speculators about the future and who on four points proclaim various conceptual theorems referring to the future, that is dependent on contact.

original: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā pubbantakappikā ca aparantakappikā ca pubbantāparantakappikā🔽ca pubbantāparantānudiṭṭhino pubbantāparantaṁ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni
analyzed: tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇā pubbantakappikā ca aparantakappikā ca pubbanta aparantakappikā 🔽ca pubbanta aparanta anudiṭṭhinaḥ pubbanta aparantam ārabbha aneka vihitāni adhimutti padāni
translated: “Therein, bhikkhus, in regard to those recluses and brahmins who are speculators about the past and the future and who on four points proclaim various conceptual theorems referring to the past and the future, that is dependent on contact.🔽“Therein, bhikkhus, in regard to those recluses and brahmins who are speculators about the past and who on four grounds proclaim various conceptual theorems referring to the past, that is dependent on contact.

original: abhivadanti dvāsaṭṭhiyā vatthūhi, tadapi phassapaccayā.🔽4.3. Netaṁṭhānaṁvijjativāra
analyzed: abhivadanti dvāsaṭṭhiyāḥ vatthūhi tat api phassa paccayā  na ita ṭhāna vijja ti vāra
translated: They greet each other with sixty-two grounds. That too is dependent on contact.🔽The section on “there is no such state”

original: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā sassataṁ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṁvedissantīti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.🔽Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṁ sassataṁ
analyzed: tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇā sassata vādā sassatam attānam ca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi te vata aññatra phassā paṭisavedissanti iti na etam ṭhānam vijjati  tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ ekacca sassatikāḥ ekacca asassatikāḥ ekaccam sassata
translated: “Monks, those ascetics and brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of the beginning of things and who on four grounds proclaim the self and the world to be eternal—there is no such state.

original: ekaccaṁ asassataṁ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, te vata aññatra phassā🔽paṭisaṁvedissantīti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
analyzed: ekaccam asassatam attānam ca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi te vata aññatra phassā  paṭisavedissanti iti na etat ṭhānam vijjati
translated: “Those ascetics and brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of the beginning of things and who on four grounds proclaim that the self and the world are partly eternal and partly not eternal—there is no such state.

original: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā antānantikā antānantaṁ lokassa paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṁvedissantīti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
analyzed: tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ anta anantikāḥ anta anantam lokassa paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi te vata aññatra phassā paṭisavedissanti iti na etam ṭhānam vijjati
translated: “Those ascetics and brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of the beginning of things and who on four grounds proclaim that the self and the world are not eternal and not not eternal—there is no such state.🔽“Those ascetics and brahmins who are speculators about the beginning and the end and who on four grounds proclaim a theory about the past—there is no such state.

original: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā amarāvikkhepikā tattha tattha pañhaṁ puṭṭhā
analyzed: tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ tattha tattha pañham puṭṭhāḥ
translated: “Therein, bhikkhus, those ascetics and brahmins who are annihilationists, who proclaim the annihilation, destruction, and extermination of an existent being, on being asked about this matter,🔽

original: samānā vācāvikkhepaṁ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṁ catūhi vatthūhi, te vata aññatra phassā🔽paṭisaṁvedissantīti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.🔽Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā adhiccasamuppannikā adhiccasamuppannaṁ attānañca
analyzed: samānāḥ vācā vikkhepam āpajjanti catūhi vatthūhi te vata aññatra phassāḥ  paṭisavedissanti iti na etat ṭhānam vijjati  tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ adhiccasamuppannikāḥ adhiccasamuppannam attānam ca
translated: “Therein, bhikkhus, as to those ascetics and brahmins who are Eel-Wrigglers and on being asked about this matter wriggle like eels and give a round-about answer in regard to the four instances, it is impossible that they will experience anything apart from contact.

original: lokañca paññapenti dvīhi vatthūhi, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṁvedissantīti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.🔽Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā pubbantakappikā pubbantānudiṭṭhino pubbantaṁ
analyzed: lokañca paññapenti dvīhi vatthūhi te vata aññatra phassā paṭisavedissanti iti na etam ṭhānam vijjati  tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇā pubbanta kappikā pubbanta anudiṭṭhinaḥ pubbanta
translated: “Therein, bhikkhus, as to those ascetics and brahmins who are chance-originists and proclaim the chance origin of the self and the world in two ways, it is impossible that they will experience anything apart from contact.

original: ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti aṭṭhārasahi vatthūhi, te vata aññatra🔽phassā paṭisaṁvedissantīti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
analyzed: ārabbha aneka vihitāni adhimutti padāni abhivadanti aṭṭhārasahi vatthūhi te vata aññatra 🔽phassā paṭisavedissanti iti na etat ṭhānam vijjati
translated: “Therein, bhikkhus, as to those ascetics and brahmins who are speculators about the past and hold settled views about the past and put forward views about the past in eighteen different ways, it is impossible that they will experience anything apart from contact.

original: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā saññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṁ
analyzed: tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ uddhamāghātanikā saññīvādāḥ uddhamāghātana
translated: “Now, bhikkhus, those ascetics and brahmins who are of the view that the self after death is percipient and possesses form,🔽

original: saññiṁ attānaṁ paññapenti soḷasahi vatthūhi, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṁvedissantīti
analyzed: saññim attānam paññapenti soḷasahi vatthūhi te vata aññatra phassā paṭisavedissanti iti
translated: “There are some ascetics and Brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of Conscious Post-Mortem Survival and who on sixteen grounds proclaim the self to have consciousness after death.

original: netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.🔽Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā asaññīvādā, uddhamāghātanaṁ
analyzed: na itam ṭhānam vijjati  tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ uddhamāghātanikāḥ asaññī vādāḥ
translated: It is impossible for them to experience this apart from contact.

original: asaññiṁ attānaṁ paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṁvedissantīti
analyzed: asaññim attānam paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi te vata aññatra phassā paṭisavedissanti iti
translated: “There are some ascetics and Brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of Conscious Post-Mortem Survival and who on eight grounds proclaim the self to be unconscious after death.

original: netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.🔽Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā nevasaññīnāsaññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṁ
analyzed: na itam ṭhānam vijjati  tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ uddham āghātanikāḥ nevasaññī nāsaññī vādāḥ uddham āghātana
translated: It is impossible for them to experience this apart from contact.

original: nevasaññīnāsaññiṁ attānaṁ paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṁvedissantīti
analyzed: nevasaññīna asaññim attānam paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi te vata aññatra phassā paṭisavedissanti iti
translated: “There are some ascetics and Brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of Conscious Post-Mortem Survival and who on eight grounds proclaim the self to be neither conscious nor unconscious after death.

original: netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
analyzed: na itam ṭhānam vijjati
translated: It is impossible for them to experience this apart from contact.

original: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā ucchedavādā sato sattassa ucchedaṁ vināsaṁ
analyzed: tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ uccheda vādāḥ sataḥ sattassa ucchedam
translated: “There are some ascetics and Brahmins who are annihilationists, who proclaim the annihilation, destruction and non-existence of beings, and who on four grounds proclaim the annihilation, destruction and non-existence of a being here and now.

original: vibhavaṁ paññapenti sattahi vatthūhi, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṁvedissantīti
analyzed: vibhavam paññapenti sattahi vatthūhi te vata aññatra phassā paṭisavedissanti iti

analyzed: na itam ṭhānam vijjati  tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ diṭṭhadhamma nibbāna vādāḥ sataḥ sattassa parama diṭṭhadhamma nibbāna
translated: That is impossible.🔽“Therein, bhikkhus, those ascetics and brahmins who are of this world’s order and proclaim the purification of beings by way of this world in five ways,

analyzed: aññatra phassā paṭisavedissanti iti na etat ṭhānam vijjati

analyzed: tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇā pubbantakappikā ca aparantakappikā ca pubbanta aparantakappikā
translated: “Therein, bhikkhus, those ascetics and brahmins who are speculators about the past, speculators about the future, and speculators about the past and the future in manifold ways,

analyzed: ca pubbanta aparanta anudiṭṭhinaḥ pubbanta aparantam ārabbha aneka vihitāni adhimutti padāni

analyzed: abhivadanti dvāsaṭṭhiyā vatthūhi te vata aññatra phassā paṭisavedissanti iti na etam ṭhānam vijjati  diṭṭhigatika adhiṭṭhāna vaṭṭa kathā
translated: they will experience anything apart from contact. That is impossible.🔽… Discussion of the standpoints of the theorists

analyzed: tatra bhikkhave ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇā sassata vādā sassatam attānam ca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi ye pi te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ ekacca sassatikāḥ ekacca asassatikāḥ pe ye pi te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ
translated: “Therein, bhikkhus, those ascetics and brahmins who are eternalists and proclaim the eternity of the self and the world do so on four grounds.
