analyzed: ye pi te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ  ye pi te samaṇa brāhmaṇā pubbanta kappikā  ye pi te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ uddhamā ghātanikā saññīvādā
translated: Those ascetics and brahmins who are finitists …🔽Those ascetics and brahmins who are infinitists …

original: yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā asaññīvādā …
analyzed: ye pi te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ uddhama āghātanikāḥ asaññī vādāḥ
translated: Those ascetics and brahmins who are chance theorists …🔽Those ascetics and brahmins who are speculators about the past …🔽Those ascetics and brahmins who are speculators about the future …

original: yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā nevasaññīnāsaññīvādā …🔽yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā ucchedavādā …
analyzed: ye pi te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ uddhama āghātanikāḥ nevasaññī nāsaññī vādāḥ  ye api te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ uccheda vādāḥ
translated: Those ascetics and brahmins who are speculators about the future, holding settled views about the future, and who on forty-four grounds assert various conceptual theorems referring to the future, all of them do so on the basis of these six bases of sense contact.

original: yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādā …🔽yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā aparantakappikā …
analyzed: ye pi te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ diṭṭhadhamma nibbāna vādāḥ  ye pi te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ
translated: Those ascetics and brahmins who are annihilationists, who proclaim the annihilation, destruction, and extermination of an existent being, all of them do so on the basis of these six bases of sense contact.🔽Those ascetics and brahmins who are speculators about the past, holding settled views about the past, and who on fifty-six grounds assert various conceptual theorems referring to the past, all of them do so on the basis of these six bases of sense contact.

original: yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā pubbantakappikā ca aparantakappikā ca pubbantāparantakappikā🔽ca pubbantāparantānudiṭṭhino pubbantāparantaṁ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni
analyzed: ye pi te samaṇa brāhmaṇā pubbanta kappikā ca aparanta kappikā ca pubbanta aparanta kappikā  ca pubbanta aparanta anudiṭṭhinaḥ pubbanta aparantam ārabbha aneka vihitāni adhimutti padāni
translated: Those ascetics and brahmins who are speculators about the future, holding settled views about the future, and who on forty-four grounds assert various conceptual theorems referring to the future, all of them do so on the basis of these six bases of sense contact.🔽Those ascetics and brahmins who are speculators about the future, holding settled views about the future, and who on forty-four grounds assert various conceptual theorems referring to the future, all of them do so on the basis of these six bases of sense contact.

original: abhivadanti dvāsaṭṭhiyā vatthūhi, sabbe te chahi phassāyatanehi phussa phussa paṭisaṁvedenti🔽tesaṁ vedanāpaccayā taṇhā, taṇhāpaccayā upādānaṁ, upādānapaccayā bhavo, bhavapaccayā
analyzed: abhivadanti dvāsaṭṭhiyā vatthūhi sabbe te chahi phassa āyatanehi phussa phussa paṭisavedenti  tesam vedanā paccayā taṇhā taṇhā paccayā upādānaḥ upādāna paccayā bhavaḥ bhava paccayā
translated: Those ascetics and brahmins who are speculators about the past and the future, holding settled views about the past and the future, and who on one hundred and eight grounds assert various conceptual theorems referring to the past and the future, all of them do so on the basis of these six bases of sense contact.🔽They experience feeling through contact to be pleasant, unpleasant, or neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant.

original: jāti, jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇaṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā sambhavanti.
analyzed: jāti jāti paccayā jarā maraṇam soka parideva dukkha domanassa upāyāsā sambhavanti
translated: With feeling as condition, there arises in them craving. With craving as condition, there arises in them clinging. With clinging as condition, there arises in them existence. With existence as condition, there arises in them birth. With birth as condition, aging, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, displeasure, and despair all come to be.

original: 5. Vivaṭṭakathādi
analyzed: vivaṭṭa kathā ādi
translated: The Discussion of the Reversal of the Cycle of Existence, etc.

original: Yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu channaṁ phassāyatanānaṁ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ayaṁ imehi sabbeheva uttaritaraṁ pajānāti.
analyzed: yatas kho bhikkhave bhikkhu channam phassa āyatanānam samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam imehi sabbehi iva uttaritaram pajānāti
translated: When a bhikkhu understands as they really are the origin and passing away of the six bases of contact, their satisfaction, unsatisfactoriness, and the escape from them, he understands what transcends all these views.

original: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā pubbantakappikā vā aparantakappikā vā
analyzed: ye hi keci bhikkhave samaṇāḥ vā brāhmaṇāḥ vā pubbantakappikāḥ vā aparantakappikāḥ vā
translated: “Bhikkhus, whatever ascetics or brahmins are speculators about the past,

original: pubbantāparantakappikā vā pubbantāparantānudiṭṭhino pubbantāparantaṁ ārabbha anekavihitāni🔽adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti, sabbe te imeheva dvāsaṭṭhiyā vatthūhi antojālīkatā,
analyzed: pubbanta aparanta kappikāḥ vā pubbanta aparanta anudiṭṭhinaḥ pubbanta aparantam ārabbha aneka vihitāni  adhimutti padāni abhivadanti sabbe te imehi eva dvāsaṭṭhiyāḥ vatthūhi antojālīka tā
translated: speculating about the beginning, and put forward views about the past on the basis of the beginning,🔽all of them do so on the basis of these sixty-two cases.

original: ettha sitāva ummujjamānā ummujjanti, ettha pariyāpannā antojālīkatāva ummujjamānā ummujjanti.
analyzed: ettha sita avaḥ ummujjamānāḥ ummujjanti ettha pariyāpannāḥ ummujjamānāḥ ummujjanti
translated: Whatever they say is included within these sixty-two cases; outside of these there is none.

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, dakkho kevaṭṭo vā kevaṭṭantevāsī vā sukhumacchikena jālena
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave dakkhaḥ kevaṭṭaḥ vā kevaṭṭa antevāsī vā sukhumacchikena jālena
translated: “Suppose a skilled fisherman or his apprentice were to cast a fine meshed net into a small pond on dry land.

original: parittaṁ udakadahaṁ otthareyya. Tassa evamassa: ‘ye kho keci imasmiṁ udakadahe oḷārikā
analyzed: parittam udaka daham otthareyya tassa evam assa ye kho keci imasmin udaka dahe oḷārikā
translated: Then he might think: ‘Whatever large creatures there are in this pond, they are caught in the net, trapped in the net, caught and trapped in the net.’

original: pāṇā, sabbe te antojālīkatā. Ettha sitāva ummujjamānā ummujjanti; ettha pariyāpannā
analyzed: pāṇā sabbe te antojālīkatāḥ ettha sitā ava ummujjamānāḥ ummujjanti ettha pariyāpannā
translated: all of them are caught in the net. They are caught in the net that is drawn in,

original: antojālīkatāva ummujjamānā ummujjantī’ti;
analyzed: ummujjamānāḥ ummujjanti iti
translated: that is drawn in and caught in the net.’

original: evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye hi keci samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā pubbantakappikā vā aparantakappikā🔽vā pubbantāparantakappikā vā pubbantāparantānudiṭṭhino pubbantāparantaṁ ārabbha anekavihitāni
analyzed: evam eva kho bhikkhave ye hi keci samaṇāḥ vā brāhmaṇāḥ vā pubbantakappikāḥ vā aparantakappikā  vā pubbanta aparanta kappikāḥ vā pubbanta aparanta anudiṭṭhinaḥ pubbanta aparantam ārabbha aneka vihitāni
translated: “So too, bhikkhus, whatever ascetics and brahmins are speculators about the past, the future, or both, depending on the past and the future,

original: adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti, sabbe te imeheva dvāsaṭṭhiyā vatthūhi antojālīkatā ettha
analyzed: adhimutti padāni abhivadanti sabbe te imehi eva dvāsaṭṭhiyāḥ vatthūhi antojālīkatāḥ ettha
translated: and who proclaim a variety of speculative views about the past and the future, all of them do so on the basis of these sixty-two views.🔽They are caught in the net, caught in the net that is drawn in,

original: sitāva ummujjamānā ummujjanti, ettha pariyāpannā antojālīkatāva ummujjamānā ummujjanti.
analyzed: sita avaḥ ummujjamānāḥ ummujjanti ettha pariyāpannāḥ antojālīkata avaḥ ummujjamānāḥ ummujjanti
translated: caught in the net that is drawn in and caught in the net.

original: Ucchinnabhavanettiko, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa kāyo tiṭṭhati.🔽Yāvassa kāyo ṭhassati, tāva naṁ dakkhanti devamanussā.
analyzed: ucchinna bhavanettikaḥ bhikkhave tathāgatassa kāyaḥ tiṭṭhati  yāva assa kāyaḥ tāva nam dakkhanti deva manussā
translated: “Bhikkhus, the Tathagata’s physical body is severed from the fetter.🔽As long as his body endures, devas and humans will see him;

original: Kāyassa bhedā uddhaṁ jīvitapariyādānā na naṁ dakkhanti devamanussā.
analyzed: kāyassa bhedāḥ uddham jīvita pariyādānā na nam dakkhanti deva manussā
translated: but with the breakup of the body, after death, devas and humans will not see him.🔽“Bhikkhus, the Tathagata’s physical body is severed from the fetter.

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ambapiṇḍiyā vaṇṭacchinnāya yāni kānici ambāni vaṇṭapaṭibandhāni, sabbāni tāni tadanvayāni bhavanti;
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave amba piṇḍiyā vaṇṭa chinnāya yāni kānici ambāni vaṇṭa paṭibandhāni sabbāni tāni tad anvayāni bhavanti
translated: Just as when a bunch of mangoes has been struck by lightning, all the mangoes in the bunch are ruined and unfit to eat,

original: evameva kho, bhikkhave, ucchinnabhavanettiko tathāgatassa kāyo tiṭṭhati,
analyzed: evam eva kho bhikkhave ucchinna bhavanettikaḥ tathāgatassa kāyaḥ tiṭṭhati
translated: so too, when the guide to becoming is cut off, the Tathāgata’s body persists,

original: yāvassa kāyo ṭhassati, tāva naṁ dakkhanti devamanussā,
analyzed: yāva assa kāyaḥ tāva nam dakkhanti deva manussā
translated: but as long as the body persists, gods and humans will see him.

original: kāyassa bhedā uddhaṁ jīvitapariyādānā na naṁ dakkhanti devamanussā”ti.
analyzed: kāyassa bhedāḥ uddham jīvita pariyādānā na nam dakkhanti deva manussā ti
translated: But when the body breaks up and his life ends, gods and humans will no longer see him.”

original: Evaṁ vutte, āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: evam vutte āyasmai ānandaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: When this was said, Ven. Ānanda said to the Blessed One,

original: “acchariyaṁ, bhante, abbhutaṁ, bhante, ko nāmo ayaṁ, bhante, dhammapariyāyo”ti?🔽“Tasmātiha tvaṁ, ānanda, imaṁ dhammapariyāyaṁ atthajālantipi naṁ dhārehi, dhammajālantipi
analyzed: acchariya bhante abbhuta bhante kaḥ nāma aya bhante dhammapariyāyaḥ ti  tasmā ati ha tvam ānanda imam dhammapariyāyam attha jāla antipi nam dhārehi dhamma jāla antipi
translated: “It’s amazing, lord. It’s astounding, how well that has been said by the Blessed One:

original: naṁ dhārehi, brahmajālantipi naṁ dhārehi, diṭṭhijālantipi naṁ dhārehi, anuttaro saṅgāmavijayotipi naṁ dhārehī”ti.
analyzed: nam dhārehi brahma jālantipi nam dhārehi diṭṭhi jālantipi nam dhārehi anuttaraḥ nam dhārehi iti
translated: “So, Ānanda, remember this Dhamma exposition as the ‘Discourse on the Root of All Things,’ the ‘Discourse on the Root of the Dhamma,’ the ‘Discourse on the Root of the Holy Life,’ the ‘Discourse on the Root of Views,’ and the ‘Incomparable Victory in Battle.’”

original: Idamavoca bhagavā.
analyzed: idam avoca bhagavān
translated: That is what the Blessed One said.

original: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.
analyzed: attamanāḥ te bhikkhū bhagavataḥ bhāsitam abhinandunti
translated: and the bhikkhus were uplifted and greatly rejoiced in what was said by the Fortunate One.

original: Imasmiñca pana veyyākaraṇasmiṁ bhaññamāne dasasahassī lokadhātu akampitthāti.
analyzed: imasmin ca pana veyyākaraṇasmiṃ bhaññamāne dasa sahassī lokadhātu akampittha ati
translated: And while this explanation was being spoken the ten thousand world-element shook.

original: Brahmajālasuttaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ paṭhamaṁ.
analyzed: brahmajāla suttam niṭṭhitam paṭhama
translated: The Brahmajāla Sutta is finished, the first.
